Center, Chemical Technology Division, Oak Ridge National Laboratory, Oak Ridge, TN 37831-6226, United States; Selvaraj, P.T., Bioprocessing R. and D. Center, Chemical Technology Division, Oak Ridge National Laboratory, Oak Ridge, TN 37831-6226, United States
Abstract: A combined chemical and biological process for the recycling of flue gas desulfurization (FGD) gypsum into calcium carbonate and elemental sulfur is demonstrated. In this process, a mixed culture of sulfate-reducing bacteria (SRB) utilizes sewage digest as its carbon source to reduce FGD gypsum to hydrogen sulfide. The sulfide is then oxidized to elemental sulfur via reaction with ferric sulfate, and accumulating calcium ions are precipitated to calcium carbonate using carbon dioxide. Employing anaerobically digested-municipal sewage sludge (AD-MSS) medium as a carbon source, SRB in serum bottles demonstrated an FGD gypsum reduction rate of 8 mg dm-3h-1 (109 cells)-1. A chemostat with continuous addition of both AD-MSS medium and gypsum exhibited sulfate reduction rates as high as 1.3 kg FGD gypsum m-3 day-1. The increased biocatalyst density afforded by cell immobilization in a columnar reactor allowed a productivity of 152 mg SO4 dm-3 h-1 or 6.6 kg FGD gypsum m-3 day-1. Both reactors demonstrated 100% conversion of sulfate, with 75-100% recovery of elemental sulfur and as high as 70% COD utilization. Calcium carbonate was recovered from the reactor effluent upon precipitation using carbon dioxide. The formation of two marketable products-elemental sulfur and calcium carbonate-from FGD gypsum sludge, combined with the use of a low-cost carbon source and further improvements in reactor design, promises to offer an attractive alternative to the landfilling of FGD gypsum.A combined chemical and biological process for the recycling of flue gas desulfurization (FGD) gypsum into calcium carbonate and elemental sulfur is demonstrated. In this process, a mixed culture of sulfate-reducing bacteria (SRB) utilizes sewage digest as its carbon source to reduce FGD gypsum to hydrogen sulfide. The sulfide is then oxidized to elemental sulfur via reaction with ferric sulfate, and accumulating calcium ions are precipitated to calcium carbonate using carbon dioxide. Employing anaerobically digested-municipal sewage sludge (AD-MSS) medium as a carbon source, SRB in serum bottles demonstrated an FGD gypsum reduction rate of 8 mg dm-3 h-1 (109 cells)-1. A chemostat with continuous addition of both AD-MSS medium and gypsum exhibited sulfate reduction rates as high as 1.3 kg FGD gypsum m-3 day-1. The increased biocatalyst density afforded by cell immobilization in a columnar reactor allowed a productivity of 152 mg SO4 dm-3 h-1 or 6.6 kg FGD gypsum m-3 day-1. Both reactors demonstrated 100% conversion of sulfate, with 75-100% recovery of elemental sulfur and as high as 70% COD utilization. Calcium carbonate was recovered from the reactor effluent upon precipitation using carbon dioxide. The formation of two marketable products - elemental sulfur and calcium carbonate - from FGD gypsum sludge, combined with the use of a low-cost carbon source and further improvements in reactor design, promises to offer an attractive alternative to the landfilling of FGD gypsum.

Authors: Kaufmann U., Kunzer M., Merz C., Akasaki I., Amano H.
Title: Light generating carrier recombination and impurities in Wurtzite GaN/Al2O3 grown by MOCVD
Affiliations: Fraunhofer-Inst for Applied Solid, State Physics, Freiburg, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Kaufmann, U., Fraunhofer-Inst for Applied Solid, State Physics, Freiburg, Germany; Kunzer, M., Fraunhofer-Inst for Applied Solid, State Physics, Freiburg, Germany; Merz, C., Fraunhofer-Inst for Applied Solid, State Physics, Freiburg, Germany; Akasaki, I., Fraunhofer-Inst for Applied Solid, State Physics, Freiburg, Germany; Amano, H., Fraunhofer-Inst for Applied Solid, State Physics, Freiburg, Germany
Abstract: We have studied by photoluminescence (PL) and optically detected magnetic resonance (ODMR) undoped, n-doped and p-doped thin wurtzite GaN layers grown by metal-organic chemical vapor deposition on sapphire substrates. From the PL data for free excitons an accurate value of the free A-type exciton binding energy and a more accurate estimate for the hole effective mass is deduced. The localization energies of the Mg and the Zn neutral acceptor bound excitons are found to be in good agreement with Haynes' rule. A sharp emission line, assigned to free electron recombination at a 116 meV shallow acceptor, together, with three additional weak zero-phonon-lines (ZPLs), assigned to distant donor-acceptor (DA) pairs, are reported for the first time. The chemical nature of this acceptor and that of three residual donors, inferred from the DA pair ZPLs, is discussed. The effects of strain in thin GaN layers on a dissimilar substrate like sapphire are emphasized with respect to the energetic position of narrow PL lines. The ODMR data obtained for undoped, Mg-doped and Zn-doped GaN layers provide insight into the recombination mechanisms responsible for the broad yellow (2.25 eV), the violet (3.15 eV) and the blue (2.8 eV) PL bands, respectively. The ODMR results for Mg and Zn also show that these acceptors do not behave effective mass like and indicate that the acceptor hole is mainly localized in the nearest neighbor shell surrounding the acceptor core.
Index Keywords: Alumina; Band structure; Binding energy; Charge carriers; Crystal impurities; Excitons; Magnetic resonance; Metallorganic chemical vapor deposition; Photoluminescence; Sapphire; Semiconductor growth; Substrates; Donor acceptor pairs; Free excitons; Gallium nitride; Hole; Neutral acceptor; Optically detected magnetic resonance; Zero phonon lines; Semiconducting gallium compounds

Authors: Kayhanian M., Rich D.
Title: Sludge management using the biodegradable organic fraction of municipal solid waste as a primary substrate
Affiliations: Dept. of Civ. and Environ. Eng., United States; UC Davis Biogasification Project, United States; Sacramento Office of CH2M Hill, United States; Dept. of Civ. and Environ. Eng., University of California, Davis, CA 95616, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kayhanian, M., Dept. of Civ. and Environ. Eng., United States, UC Davis Biogasification Project, United States, Dept. of Civ. and Environ. Eng., University of California, Davis, CA 95616, United States; Rich, D., Sacramento Office of CH2M Hill, United States
Abstract: An innovative anaerobic composting process has been used to manage wastewater treatment plant sludges using the biodegradable organic fraction (BOF) found in municipal solid waste (MSW) as a primary substrate. Three different types of wastewater treatment plant sludges (primary, thickened activated, and digested) were commingled with a simulated biodegradable organic fraction of municipal solid waste and used as a feedstock. Digester performance was evaluated for each feedstock under similar retention times, a constant total solids content, and a constant C:N ratio. Additional aspects of the process which have been analyzed include volume reduction, air emission, and humus characteristics. Results obtained indicate that stable and robust digestion was achieved using organic loading rates of 6.5-8 g biodegradable volatile solids per kilogram active reactor mass per day. Under these organic loading rates, methane gas production rates as high as 0.36 m3/kg biodegradable volatile solids added per day were obtained, gassifying approximately half the dry mass of the feedstock. Substrate volume reduction through the process was ~65-69% as compared with the same quantities of sludge and MSW in a well-compacted landfill. The emissions produced from anaerobic digestion and aerobic biodrying are found to have no adverse effect on human heath and the environment. The humus produced is a fine, odorless, and pathogen-free material with metal pollutant concentrations well below the 'clean sludge' standards specified by EPA Part 503 of the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (U.S. EPA).
Author Keywords: composting; digestion; emission; sludge; solid waste
Index Keywords: ammonia; biogas; nitrogen; volatile fatty acid; anaerobic digestion; article; biodegradation; cation exchange; composting; pH; priority journal; sludge clarification; solid waste management; waste water management

Authors: Kazanci N., Gevrek A.I.
Title: The effects of geothermal processes on facies development in sedimentary fill of Quaternary Nevsehir - Acigol maar lake, central Anatolia, Turkey
Affiliations: Jeoloji Muhendisligi Bolumu, Ankara Univ, 06100 Ankata, Turkey
Authors with affiliations: Kazanci, N., Jeoloji Muhendisligi Bolumu, Ankara Univ, 06100 Ankata, Turkey; Gevrek, A.I., Jeoloji Muhendisligi Bolumu, Ankara Univ, 06100 Ankata, Turkey
Abstract: The Nevsehir-Acigol maar is one of the eruption centers of Quaternary volcanism in central Anatolia. The Maar-lake fill contains clastic, chemical and organic deposits, including high-calorific peats formed in the Lake Holocene. The main (host) sediments of the infill are tuffaceous sandy mudstones. The other accessory facies, controlled mainly by climate, are peats and plant-bearing mudstones, brecciate mudstones, limestones and also travertines originated by thermal waters at the top of the succession. According to the C.14 dating of the peats, they formed c2000 yr BP; their calorific values are 2400 to 3165 kCal/kg. These values are very high, considering the immaturity of the peats. It is thought that the lake was primarily dependent on climate; and deposition was further controlled by the hydrothermal system. The associated heat flow played an important role in sedimentation by creating a micro-climatic niche, where late-Quaternary (cold regional climate) vegetation could flourish and form substantial peat deposits. The heat flow through the groundwater and clastic sediments must have been crucial during the high maturation of the peat deposits.
Index Keywords: facies distribution; geothermal processes; maar; peat; Quaternary; Quternary; sedimentation; Turkey, Anatolia, Nevsehir-Acigol Lake

Authors: Kazumata K., Tanaka N., Ishikawa T., Kuroda S., Houkin K., Mitsumori K.
Title: Dissociation of vasoreactivity to acetazolamide and hypercapnia: Comparative study in patients with chronic occlusive major cerebral artery disease
Affiliations: Department of Neurosurgery, Hokkaido Univ. School of Medicine, Hokkaido Neurosurgical Mem. Hospital, Sapporo, Japan; Department of Neurology, North Shore University Hospital, 300 Community Dr, Manhasset, NY 11030, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kazumata, K., Department of Neurology, North Shore University Hospital, 300 Community Dr, Manhasset, NY 11030, United States; Tanaka, N.; Ishikawa, T.; Kuroda, S.; Houkin, K.; Mitsumori, K., Department of Neurosurgery, Hokkaido Univ. School of Medicine, Hokkaido Neurosurgical Mem. Hospital, Sapporo, Japan
Abstract: Background and Purpose: The aim of this study was to corn pare the effect of vasodilative stimuli for the measurement of cerebrovascular reactivity obtained by acetazolamide and hypercapnia in patients with chronic occlusive major cerebral artery disease. Methods: We examined 24 patients with unilateral occlusive lesions of a major cerebral artery using the 333Xe inhalation technique and single-photon emission CT. Regional cerebral blood flow (CBF) was measured during a resting state, during inhalation of 5% CO2, and 15 minutes after the administration of acetazolamide consecutively in the same patients. Normative values of resting CBF and acetazolamide reactivity were obtained in 21 normal subjects. Results: All patients with the exception of 1 showed an increase in CBF during hypercapnia ipsilateral to the occlusive lesion. Ipsilateral acetazolamide reactivity was preserved in 13 patients. Conversely, 11 patients showed an absent response or paradoxical CBF reduction. Ipsilateral CO2 reactivity did not correlate with acetazolamide reactivity when all 24 patients were, considered. However, there was a significant correlation between acetazolamide and CO2 in the 13 patients who showed preserved acetazolamide reactivity (r = .60, P<.05). No significant correlation was present in the remaining 11 patients with reduced acetazolamide reactivity. Although significant blood pressure augmentation was observed in hypercapnia, we could not find a correlation between change of blood pressure and CO2 reactivity. Conclusions: Acetazolamide identified patients with reduced vasomotor reactivity who appeared to have preserved CO2 reactivity. Acetazolamide testing may be useful in the assessment of cerebral hemodynamics. However, further investigations are necessary to assess the clinical utility of these tests.
Author Keywords: acetazolamide; cerebral blood flow; hypercapnia; vasomotor reactivity
Index Keywords: acetazolamide; carbon dioxide; adult; aged; article; blood flow velocity; brain blood flow; clinical article; drug effect; female; human; hypercapnia; male; occlusive cerebrovascular disease; priority journal; vasodilatation; vasomotor reflex

Authors: Keating Terry J.
Title: Facts and values, cars and smog: analytical perspectives of stakeholders in air quality and transportation planning in Los Angeles, CA
Source title: International Symposium on Technology and Society
Affiliations: Univ of North Carolina, Chapel Hill, United States
Authors with affiliations: Keating, Terry J., Univ of North Carolina, Chapel Hill, United States
Abstract: Technical policy decisions can be thought of as resulting from two models: an environmental model and a preference model. The environmental model is a description of the physical and social systems affected by the policy decision. The preference model is a description of the preferences of the decision maker for the outcomes predicted by the environmental model. In many technical policy making processes, the development of the environmental model is delegated to technical experts. In these processes, efforts to involve stakeholders tend to focus on characterizing the stakeholders' preferences for various outcomes. Such efforts fail to recognize that stakeholders differ in their description of the problem as well as in their preferences. This paper presents techniques for characterizing differences in stakeholder's analytical perspectives, for exploring the effect of these differences on the structure and content of environmental models, and for estimating the impact of these differences on policy decisions. By illuminating these relationships, these techniques will contribute to a better understanding of the role of experts and other stakeholders in addressing complex policy issues. The application of these techniques in the context of air pollution and transportation planning in Los Angeles will be discussed.
Index Keywords: Air pollution; Air quality; Automobiles; Decision making; Environmental protection; Public policy; Risk assessment; Social aspects; Technology; Transportation; Urban planning; Democracy; Environmental policy; Experts; Policy decision; Smog; Stakeholders; Environmental engineering

Authors: Keeling C.D., Chin J.F.S., Whorf T.P.
Title: Increased activity of northern vegetation inferred from atmospheric CO2 measurements
Affiliations: Scripps Institution of Oceanography, San Diego, CA 92093-0220, United States
Authors with affiliations: Keeling, C.D., Scripps Institution of Oceanography, San Diego, CA 92093-0220, United States; Chin, J.F.S., Scripps Institution of Oceanography, San Diego, CA 92093-0220, United States; Whorf, T.P., Scripps Institution of Oceanography, San Diego, CA 92093-0220, United States
Abstract: THROUGHOUT the Northern Hemisphere the concentration of atmospheric carbon dioxide rises in winter and declines in summer, mainly in response to the seasonal growth in land vegetation. In the far north the amplitude of the seasonal cycle, peak to trough, is between 15 and 20 parts per million by volume. The annual amplitude diminishes southwards to about 3 p.p.m. near the Equator, owing to the diminishing seasonality of plant activity towards the tropics. In spite of atmospheric mixing processes, enough spatial variability is retained in the seasonal cycle of CO2 to reveal considerable regional detail in seasonal plant activity. Here we report that the annual amplitude of the seasonal CO2 cycle has increased by 20%, as measured in Hawaii, and by 40% in the Arctic, since the early 1960s. These increases are accompanied by phase advances of about 7 days during the declining phase of the cycle, suggesting a lengthening of the growing season. In addition, the annual amplitudes show maxima which appear to reflect a sensitivity to global warming episodes that peaked in 1981 and 1990. We propose that the amplitude increases reflect increasing assimilation of CO2 by land plants in response to climate changes accompanying recent rapid increases in temperature.
Index Keywords: carbon dioxide; air temperature; arctic climate; article; atmosphere; carbon dioxide fixation; greenhouse effect; nonhuman; plant growth; priority journal; seasonal variation; vegetation; Embryophyta; carbon dioxide; carbon dioxide enrichment; climate change; climatic change; global change; growing season; Arctic; USA, Hawaii

Authors: Keislar Robert E., Bowen John L., Fujita Eric M., Lawson Douglas R., Pierson William R.
Title: Effect of oxygenated fuels on ambient carbon monoxide concentrations in Provo, Utah
Source title: Proceedings of the Air & Waste Management Association's Annual Meeting & Exhibition
Authors with affiliations: Keislar, Robert E.; Bowen, John L.; Fujita, Eric M.; Lawson, Douglas R.; Pierson, William R.
Abstract: The objective of this study is to evaluate a new method to determine whether there is a measurable reduction in ambient carbon monoxide concentrations in Provo, Utah during the fall-winter period of oxygenated fuel usage. Measurements of ambient concentrations of carbon monoxide (CO) and carbon dioxide (CO2) were taken at a variety of sites in Provo and Salt Lake City (as a control site) for three five-day work-weeks (phases): one before, one during, and one after the 1994-95 oxygenated fuel season. Our results show that nearly all the observed ambient CO at the study sites can be attributed to mobile sources. Using five separate numerical techniques, we have investigated the change in background-corrected CO/CO2 concentration ratios from Provo, after normalization by the Salt Lake City control site concentration ratios. Two methods show no consistent pattern of CO reductions at all Provo sites during oxygenated fuel season. Three of the methods show a consistent pattern; however, no CO reduction is significant at the 95 percent confidence level for any one site using more than one numerical technique, and only at a confidence level of approx.80 percent does an upper limit of a 9-10 percent mean reduction in the observed CO/CO2 ratios become significant for morning rush-hour samples. For cold-start samples taken in a parking garage, two methods show upper limits of 15 percent and 35 percent reductions at confidence levels of 82 percent and 91 percent, respectively. These results may not account for possible CO2 contamination from space heating. Other contamination effects, limitations of the method, and recommendations for future application of the method are discussed.
Index Keywords: Carbon dioxide; Carbon monoxide; Contamination; Effects; Numerical methods; Reduction; Contamination effects; Oxygenated fuels; Fuels

Authors: Kelley D.B., Hunter D.G., Gardner P.S., Weinand D.C., Tiné A., Tieszen L.L.
Title: The McLelland and Joe Clark Sites: Protohistoric-Historic Caddo Farmsteads in the Red River Valley of Northwest Louisiana
Authors with affiliations: Kelley, D.B.; Hunter, D.G.; Gardner, P.S.; Weinand, D.C.; Tiné, A.; Tieszen, L.L.
Abstract: Recent excavations at two sites located along the Red River in southern Bossier Parish, Louisiana have provided important data on late Protohistoric to early Historic Caddo farmsteads. The McLelland site (16BO236) contained the remains of two houses, 68 pit features, and seven burials. The other site, Joe Clark (16BO237), yielded one house, 11 pit features, and one burial. The sites appear to have been occupied year-round for a period of about 40 to 60 years. Carbonized plant remains recovered through flotation and waterscreening indicate that corn, beans, and squash were cultivated, along with chenopod, sumpweed, and sunflower. Several species of nuts, particularly hickories and acorns, and a variety of wild fruits, including persimmons, grapes, elderberries, and plums or cherries, were collected from the surrounding forests. The principal game taken were white-tailed deer and fish. Chronological data derived from radiocarbon dates and ceramic analysis indicate that the sites were occupied between about A.D. 1650 and 1710. Ethnohistorical information from the Bienville expedition of 1700 suggests that the occupants of the sites may have been a group called the Nakasas.

Authors: Kelly K.J., Bailey B.K., Coburn T., Clark W., Lissiuk P.
Title: Federal test procedure emissions test results from ethanol variable-fuel vehicle chevrolet luminas
Affiliations: National Renewable Energy Lab.; Automotive Testing Labs.; Environmental Research and Development Corp.
Authors with affiliations: Kelly, K.J., National Renewable Energy Lab.; Bailey, B.K., National Renewable Energy Lab.; Coburn, T., National Renewable Energy Lab.; Clark, W., Automotive Testing Labs.; Lissiuk, P., Environmental Research and Development Corp.
Abstract: The first round of Federal Test Procedure (FTP) emissions testing of variable-fuel ethanol vehicles from the U.S. Federal fleet was recently completed. The vehicles tested include 21 variable-fuel E85 1992 and 1993 Chevrolet Lumina sedans and an equal number of standard gasoline Luminas. Results presented include a comparison of regulated exhaust and evaporative emissions and a discussion of the levels of air toxics, as well as the calculated ozone-forming potential of the measured emissions. Two private emissions laboratories tested vehicles taken from the general population of Federal fleet vehicles in the Washington, D.C., and Chicago metropolitan regions. Testing followed the standard U.S. Environmental Protection Agency's FTP and detailed fuel changeover procedures as developed in the Auto/Oil Air Quality Improvement Research Program. Variable-fuel vehicles were tested on single respective batches of E85, E50, and California Phase 2 reformulated gasoline (RFG) blended specifically for this test program. © 1995 Society of Automotive Engineers, Inc.
Index Keywords: Air quality; Environmental Protection Agency; Ethanol; Fleet operations; Reformulated gasoline; Vehicles; Air quality improvement; Evaporative emission; Federal test procedures; General population; Metropolitan regions; Ozone-forming potential; Research programs; U.S. Environmental Protection Agency; Software testing

Authors: Kelly K.J., Bailey B.K., Coburn T.C., Clark W., Eudy L., Lissiuk P.
Title: FTP emissions test results from flexible-fuel methanol dodge spirits and ford econoline vans
Affiliations: National Renewable Energy Lab.; Automotive Testing Laboratories, Inc.; ManTech Environmental Technology, Inc.; Environmental Research and Development Corp.
Authors with affiliations: Kelly, K.J., National Renewable Energy Lab.; Bailey, B.K., National Renewable Energy Lab.; Coburn, T.C., National Renewable Energy Lab.; Clark, W., Automotive Testing Laboratories, Inc.; Eudy, L., ManTech Environmental Technology, Inc.; Lissiuk, P., Environmental Research and Development Corp.
Abstract: The first round of emissions testing of flexible fuel methanol vehicles from the U.S. federal fleet was completed in 1995. The vehicles tested include 71 flexible fuel M85 1993 Dodge Spirits, 16 flexible fuel 1994 M85 Ford Econoline Vans, and a similar number of standard gasoline Dodge Spirits and E150 Ford Econoline Vans. Results presented include a comparison of regulated exhaust and evaporative emissions and a discussion of the levels of air toxins, and the ozone-forming potential (OFP) of the measured emissions. Three private emissions laboratories tested vehicles taken from the general population of federal fleet vehicles in the Washington D.C., New York City, Detroit, Chicago, and Denver metropolitan regions. Testing followed the standard U.S. Environmental Protection Agency's Federal Test Procedures (FTPs) and detailed fuel changeover procedures as developed in the Auto/Oil Air Quality Improvement Research Program. Flexible fuel vehicles (FFVs) were tested using fuels consisting of 85% methanol to 15% gasoline (M85), 50% methanol to 50% gasoline (M50), and California Phase 2 reformulated gasoline (RFG). All vehicle/fuel combinations showed emissions well below the certification standards (including the more stringent Tier I standards). At these levels, the magnitude of the fuel-to-fuel differences in emissions from FFVs was relatively low. In general, there appeared to be a small drop in non-methane hydrocarbons (NMHCs), and carbon monoxide (CO), and an increase in oxides of nitrogen (NOx) for M85 compared to the same vehicles tested on RFG. The OFP (expressed in grams of ozone per mile) from the M85 tests were 40% to 50% lower than the RFG tests performed on the Dodge Spirits and Ford Econoline vans. The M85 tests also showed lower levels of benzene and 1,3-butadiene but increased formaldehyde. © 1995 Society of Automotive Engineers, Inc.
Index Keywords: Air quality; Carbon monoxide; Environmental Protection Agency; Fleet operations; Methanol; Methanol fuels; Ozone; Software testing; Trucks; Air quality improvement; Certification standards; Federal test procedures; Flexible fuel vehicles; Metropolitan regions; Non-methane hydrocarbons; Ozone-forming potential; U.S. Environmental Protection Agency; Reformulated gasoline

Authors: Kerminen V.-M., Wexler A.S.
Title: The occurrence of sulfuric acid-water nucleation in plumes: Urban environment
Source title: Tellus, Series B: Chemical and Physical Meteorology
Affiliations: Finnish Meteorological Institute, Air Quality Department, Sahaajankatu 20E, FIN-00810 Helsinki, Finland; Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Delaware, Newark, DE 19716, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kerminen, V.-M., Finnish Meteorological Institute, Air Quality Department, Sahaajankatu 20E, FIN-00810 Helsinki, Finland; Wexler, A.S., Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Delaware, Newark, DE 19716, United States
Abstract: The production of new sulfuric acid-water particles via homogeneous nucleation was examined in plumes originating from urban point sources. The problem was approached by modeling the time development of the gas phase sulfuric acid concentration during the plume transport, and thereby identifying the meteorological, source-related, and environmental variables governing the behavior of this system. The development of the plume nucleation probability was shown to be dictated by a complicated and nonlinear interaction between the plume dispersion, chemistry, and condensation of sulfuric acid from the gas phase. For all the simulated plumes, those originating from stronger sources and dispersing at slower rates, or having higher SO2 to fine paniculate matter ratios, or higher SO2 to NOx concentration ratios, showed greater nucleation probabilities indicative of a higher capability for producing new particles. Nucleation was also favored by cool and humid ambient conditions, greater actinic flux, and higher background hydrocarbon concentrations. The most effective way to decrease the plume nucleation probability was to decrease SO2 emissions alone. Reducing NOx or particle emissions may decrease the total paniculate mass but leads to higher plume nucleation probabilities, which is likely to increase particle number concentrations farther downwind of the source.
Index Keywords: gas phase sulphuric acid; plume nucleation probability; plume transport; sulphur dioxide emission; sulphuric acid/water nucleation; urban acid source

Authors: Khan M.R., Popiel E., Reynolds J.G.
Title: Designing fuels for the environment: Reformulated gasoline
Affiliations: New Technology Research Section, Texaco R and D, Beacon, NY, United States; Analytical Section, Texaco R and D, Beacon, NY, United States; Lawrence Livermore Natl. Laboratory, Livermore, CA, United States; Lawrence Livermore Natl. Laboratory, P.O. Box 808, L-365, Livermore, CA 94551, United States
Authors with affiliations: Khan, M.R., New Technology Research Section, Texaco R and D, Beacon, NY, United States; Popiel, E., Analytical Section, Texaco R and D, Beacon, NY, United States; Reynolds, J.G., Lawrence Livermore Natl. Laboratory, Livermore, CA, United States, Lawrence Livermore Natl. Laboratory, P.O. Box 808, L-365, Livermore, CA 94551, United States
Abstract: The Clean Air Act of 1990 has impacted the gasoline markets of the United States. Additives and reformulated gasoline have already been implemented in some cases to comply with regulations and emission standards, and gasoline will continue to be reformulated. The regulations for reformulated gasoline have been divided into Phases I and II, starting in 1995 and 2000, respectively, the second phase having more stringent requirements. Phase I is divided into two compliance models - Simple and Complex. These models are designed to facilitate the determination of fuel formulation compliance without the expense of extensive testing of motor performance. The Simple Model can be used from 1995 to 1997, and the Complex Model from 1997 on. Diesel fuels are also impacted by the Clean Air Act. Other programs - such as CO oxygenate and California Phase 2 - have been initiated in response to air quality issues.
Author Keywords: Clean Air Act; Fuel formulation; Gasoline refining; Reformulated gasoline
Index Keywords: Additives; Air pollution control; Air quality; Carbon monoxide; Diesel fuels; Gas emissions; Public policy; Standards; Clean air act; Fuel formulation compliance; Oxygenate; Reformulated gasoline; Gasoline

Authors: Khanna I.K.
Title: Towards a Better Environment : Through Transportation Air Pollution Control
Source title: Journal of the Institution of Engineers (India): Environmental Engineering Division
Affiliations: Mechanical Engineering Department, I G Govt. College of Engineering, Sagar 470 001, India
Authors with affiliations: Khanna, I.K., Mechanical Engineering Department, I G Govt. College of Engineering, Sagar 470 001, India
Abstract: In large Indian cities, one of the major sources of air pollution is vehicular emission. In some cities, this-contributes as much as 40% of total air pollution. In order to improve environmental quality this largest single source of air pollution has to be controlled. In this paper a transportation policy planning model of Delhi's urban transportation system is presented. The model has been used to estimate the results of various policies designed to reduce transportation air pollution. The policies range from technological changes to government imposed legislation.

Authors: Khodadadi A.A., Hudgins R.R., Silveston P.L.
Title: Composition Modulation of the Fischer-Tropsch Synthesis over a Supported Cobalt Catalyst
Affiliations: Department of Chemical Engineering, University of Waterloo, Waterloo, Ont. N2L 3G1, Canada; Energy Research Laboratory, CANMET, Western Research Centre, Devon, Alta.T0C 1E0, Canada

N2L 3G1, Canada; Silveston, P.L., Department of Chemical Engineering, University of Waterloo, Waterloo, Ont. N2L 3G1, Canada
Abstract: Different cycling strategies are explored to see if carbon chain growth can be enhanced and methane formation suppressed. Of the strategies considered, bang-bang cycling between H2 and CO feeds substantially increased the consumption of CO and H2, but the formation of higher hydrocarbons and olefins was reduced. The best strategy for longer chain hydrocarbons suitable for jet or diesel fuels was found to be cycling between syngas mixtures. None of the cycling strategies was able to produce C8+ or low-molar mass olefin yields that matched yields found in steady-state operation.
Author Keywords: Cobalt catalyst; Composition modulation; Fischer-Tropsch synthesis; Periodic operation

Title: Transient and steady-state conduction in sol-gel PbZr0.53Ti0.47O3 (PZT) films
Affiliations: Lab. de Céramique, EPFL, CH-1015 Lausanne, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Kholkin, A.L., Lab. de Céramique, EPFL, CH-1015 Lausanne, Switzerland; Tagantsev, A.K., Lab. de Céramique, EPFL, CH-1015 Lausanne, Switzerland; Colla, E.L., Lab. de Céramique, EPFL, CH-1015 Lausanne, Switzerland; Brooks, K.G., Lab. de Céramique, EPFL, CH-1015 Lausanne, Switzerland; Setter, N., Lab. de Céramique, EPFL, CH-1015 Lausanne, Switzerland
Abstract: I-V characteristics have been studied in PbZr0.53Ti0.47O3 thin films prepared by the sol-gel technique. The pronounced influence of measurement time, temperature, film thickness and electrode material on I-V response has been observed. The transition from initial quasilinear to strongly superlinear behavior with increasing field is attributed to change-over from a transient current regime to steady-state conduction governed by Schottky emission over the barrier between the film and metal electrode.

Authors: Kikuchi E., Ogura M., Terasaki I., Goto Y.
Title: Selective reduction of nitric oxide with methane on gallium and indium containing H-ZSM-5 catalysts: Formation of active sites by solid-state ion exchange
Affiliations: Department of Applied Chemistry, School of Science and Engineering, Waseda University, 3-4-1 Okubo, Shinjuku-ku, Tokyo 169, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Kikuchi, E., Department of Applied Chemistry, School of Science and Engineering, Waseda University, 3-4-1 Okubo, Shinjuku-ku, Tokyo 169, Japan; Ogura, M., Department of Applied Chemistry, School of Science and Engineering, Waseda University, 3-4-1 Okubo, Shinjuku-ku, Tokyo 169, Japan; Terasaki, I., Department of Applied Chemistry, School of Science and Engineering, Waseda University, 3-4-1 Okubo, Shinjuku-ku, Tokyo 169, Japan; Goto, Y., Department of Applied Chemistry, School of Science and Engineering, Waseda University, 3-4-1 Okubo, Shinjuku-ku, Tokyo 169, Japan
Abstract: H-ZSM-5 catalysts containing Ga and In were prepared by the ion-exchange method and by physically mixing H-ZSM-5 and Ga2O3or In2O3, and they were used in the NO reduction with methane to determine the active species of these metals, particularly of In, for this reaction. Ga-loaded H-ZSM-5 prepared by the ion-exchange method gave a higher catalytic activity than the physical mixture of Ga2O3 and H-ZSM-5, of which the catalytic activity was comparable to that of H-ZSM-5. On the contrary, both ion-exchange and physical mixing methods yielded equally high catalytic activities of In-loaded H-ZSM-5. The reduction of NO on these catalysts proceeds consecutively by way of oxidation of NO to NO2 and reduction of NO2 with CH4 to N2. With increasing heat treatment temperature, the catalytic activity of the mixture of In2O3 and H-ZSM-5 for the reduction of NO2 increased, while that for NO oxidation decreased. An IR study of OH groups on this catalyst indicated that the solid-state exchange reaction occurred between In2O3 and H-ZSM-5 leading to the increase in the number of indium cation sites and consequently the catalytic activity for NO2 reduction. © 1996 Academic Press, Inc.

Authors: Kilgroe James D., Licata Anthony
Title: Control of air pollution emissions from municipal waste combustors
Source title: Proceedings of National Waste Processing Conference
Affiliations: U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Research Triangle Park, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kilgroe, James D., U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Research Triangle Park, United States; Licata, Anthony, U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Research Triangle Park, United States
Abstract: The November 1990 Clear Air Act Amendments (CAAAs) directed EPA to establish municipal waste combustor (MWC) emission limits for particulate matter, opacity, hydrogen chloride, sulfur dioxide, nitrogen oxides, carbon monoxide, dioxins, dibenzofurans, cadmium, lead, and mercury. Revised MWC air pollution regulations were subsequently proposed by EPA on September 20, 1994, and promulgated on December 19, 1995. The MWC emission limits were based on the application of maximum achievable control technology (MACT). This paper provides a brief overview of MWC technologies, a summary of EPA's revised air pollution rules for MWCs, a review of current knowledge concerning formation and control of polychlorinated dibenzo-p-dioxins and polychlorinated dibenzofurans, and a discussion of the behavior and control of mercury in MWC flue gases.
Index Keywords: Air pollution; Air pollution control; Aromatic hydrocarbons; Flue gases; Laws and legislation; Mercury (metal); Particles (particulate matter); Particulate emissions; Emission control; Municipal waste combustors; Polychlorinated dibenzofurans; Polychlorinated dibenzoparadioxins; Combustors

Authors: Kilgroe J.D.
Title: Control of dioxin, furan, and mercury emissions from municipal waste combustors
Affiliations: U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Air and Ener. Eng. Res. Laboratory, Research Triangle Park, NC 27711, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kilgroe, J.D., U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Air and Ener. Eng. Res. Laboratory, Research Triangle Park, NC 27711, United States
Abstract: There is a significant public and scientific concern over the potential risks of air pollution emissions from municipal waste combustors (MWCs). The primary pollutants of concern are polychlorinated dibenzo-p-dioxins and dibenzofurans (PCDDs/PCDFs), and mercury (Hg). Depending on the composition of the waste and the technologies used, PCDD/PCDF emissions may range from less than 1.0 to more than 20 000 ng/dscm. Hg concentrations in MWC flue gas may range from less than 200 to more than 1000 μg/dscm. Trace organic emissions are dependent on the combustion and flue gas cleaning technologies employed and the conditions at which they are operated. Good combustion practice and dry scrubbing techniques employing fabric filter (FF) bag houses can be used to reduce average PCDD/PCDF emissions to less than 20 ng/dscm. Dry scrubbers in combination with electrostatic precipitators (ESPs) are less effective, resulting in typical PCDD/PCDF emissions of less than 75 ng/dscm. Powdered activated carbon can be injected into the flue gas to reduce Hg emissions from spray dryer (SD)/FF and SD/ESP systems to less than 0.08 mg/dscm. It can also be used to improve PCDD/PCDF capture in these systems. This article provides an overview of MWC air pollution control technologies and applicable Federal air emission control requirements. Knowledge concerning PCDD/PCDF formation is summarized, and data are provided on the performance of combustion and flue gas cleaning techniques used to control PCDD/PCDF emissions. The fundamental Hg properties which affect capture in flue gas cleaning equipment are discussed, and the results of carbon injection control tests are summarized.This article provides an overview of municipal waste combustor air pollution control technologies and applicable Federal air emission control requirement for dioxin, furan, and mercury emissions. Knowledge concerning polychlorinated dibenzo-p-dioxins and dibenzofurans (PCDD/PCDF) formation is summarized, an data are provided on the performance of combustion and flue gas cleaning techniques used to control PCDD/PCDF emissions. The fundamental Hg properties which affect capture in flue gas cleaning equipment are discussed, and the results of carbon injection control tests are summarized.
Author Keywords: Dioxin formation and control; Mercury control; Municipal waste combustors; MWC air pollution regulations
Index Keywords: Activated carbon; Air pollution control; Aromatic polymers; Combustors; Environmental protection; Flue gases; Hazardous materials; Laws and legislation; Mercury (metal); Waste incineration; Dry scrubbing techniques; Electrostatic precipitators; Municipal waste combustors; Polychlorinated dibenzo dioxins; Polychlorinated dibenzofurans; Gas emissions; activated carbon; dioxin; furan; mercury; polychlorinated dibenzodioxin; polychlorinated dibenzofuran; air pollution control; article; combustion; electricity; flue gas; law; scrubber; solid waste management; standard

Authors: Kilham S.S., Theriot E.C., Fritz S.C.
Title: Linking planktonic diatoms and climate change in the large lakes of the Yellowstone ecosystem using resource theory
Affiliations: Dept. of Biosci. and Biotechnology, Drexel University, Philadelphia, PA 19104-2875, United States; Acad. of Nat. Sci. of Philadelphia, 1900 Benjamin Franklin Parkway, Philadelphia, PA 19103-1195, United States; Dept. of Earth and Environ. Sciences, Lehigh University, 31 Williams Drive, Bethlehem, PA 18015-3188, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kilham, S.S., Dept. of Biosci. and Biotechnology, Drexel University, Philadelphia, PA 19104-2875, United States; Theriot, E.C., Acad. of Nat. Sci. of Philadelphia, 1900 Benjamin Franklin Parkway, Philadelphia, PA 19103-1195, United States; Fritz, S.C., Dept. of Earth and Environ. Sciences, Lehigh University, 31 Williams Drive, Bethlehem, PA 18015-3188, United States
Abstract: Resource-based physiology of the eight important planktonic diatom species in the large lakes of the Yellowstone region can be used to explain their relative abundances and seasonal changes. The diatoms are ranked along resource ratio gradients according to their relative abilities to grow under limitation by Si, N, P, and light. Hypotheses based on resource physiology can be integrated with observations on seasonal changes in diatom assemblages to explain the present distributions of diatoms and to test the causal factors proposed to explain diatom distributions over the Holocene. Knowledge of the limnology of these lakes and process-oriented physiology provide the basis for a more detailed interpretation of the paleorecord and a firmer basis for landscape-level transfer functions for fine-scale climate reconstruction.
Index Keywords: Bacillariophyta

Authors: Kim C., Lior N.
Title: NOx formation and control in radiatively/conductively-stabilized pulverized coal combustors: A numerical analysis
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Heat Transfer Division, (Publication) HTD
Affiliations: Dept. Mech. Eng. and Appl. Mechanics, University of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia, PA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kim, C., Dept. Mech. Eng. and Appl. Mechanics, University of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia, PA, United States; Lior, N., Dept. Mech. Eng. and Appl. Mechanics, University of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia, PA, United States
Abstract: In an attempt to study ways for reducing NOx emissions from radiatively/conductively stabilized combustors (RCSC) for pulverized coal, a comprehensive conjugate heat&mass transfer and reaction kinetics model of that combustor was developed. As compared with a simple three-reaction model, the radiation intensity distribution obtained by a more comprehensive one shows a substantial decrease in the flame region. The effect of a 10% deviation in the diffusion coefficients on the results was found to be negligible, indicating that the use of binary coefficients instead of those for a multi-component system may be good enough in such combustion modeling. Flame location was found to have little effect (∼6%) and internal wall emittance an insignificant effect, on NO emissions. However, it was found that these emissions could be lowered significantly by lowering the flame temperature, accomplished by increasing the excess air ratio.

Authors: Kim J., Burrell K.H., Groebner R.J., Hinton F.L., Sager G.T., Staebler G.M., Stambaugh R.D.
Title: Er modification by means of counter-neutral beam injection in a low-Ip plasma
Affiliations: General Atomics, PO Box 85608, San Diego, CA 92138, United States; Korea Basic Science Institute, National Fusion R. and D. Center, Taejeon, 305-333, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Kim, J., General Atomics, PO Box 85608, San Diego, CA 92138, United States, Korea Basic Science Institute, National Fusion R. and D. Center, Taejeon, 305-333, South Korea; Burrell, K.H., General Atomics, PO Box 85608, San Diego, CA 92138, United States; Groebner, R.J., General Atomics, PO Box 85608, San Diego, CA 92138, United States; Hinton, F.L., General Atomics, PO Box 85608, San Diego, CA 92138, United States; Sager, G.T., General Atomics, PO Box 85608, San Diego, CA 92138, United States; Staebler, G.M., General Atomics, PO Box 85608, San Diego, CA 92138, United States; Stambaugh, R.D., General Atomics, PO Box 85608, San Diego, CA 92138, United States
Abstract: The idea of controlling the radial electric field (Er) by means of a radial current resulting from ion orbit loss caused by counter neutral beam injection has been theoretically and experimentally investigated. A large fraction (≃ 38%) of the 75 keV deuterium ions counter-injected into a IOW-Ip plasma (≃ 0.4 MA) suffers prompt orbit loss, which forces an inward ion current to maintain charge neutrality. Monte Carlo guiding-centre orbit calculations predict a radial current of 80 A at the last closed flux surface. In these discharges, Er is negative everywhere, owing to the counter-going toroidal rotation, and exhibits a double-bump shape, in contrast to the usual positive parabolic shape for the co-injection case. The measured carbon impurity ion toroidal rotation profile shows a pedestal over the outer region where fast ions are lost, possibly due to the effect of Jrorbit x B torque. The momentum diffusion process tends to slow down and to spatially spread the Jrorbit x B torque effect. The L-H transition did not occur more quickly in these discharges than in similar co-injected discharges. © 1996 IOP Publishing Ltd.
Index Keywords: Deuterium; Diffusion in gases; Electric discharges; Electric fields; Electron transitions; Impurities; Monte Carlo methods; Particle beam injection; Plasma confinement; Tokamak devices; Ion orbit loss; Radial electric field; Beam plasma interactions

Authors: Kim Y.H., Kozai T., Kubota C., Kitaya Y.
Title: Design of a wind tunnel for plug seedlings production under artificial lighting
Affiliations: Department of Agricultural Machinery Engineering, Chonbuk National University, Chonju 560-756, South Korea; Department of Bioproduction Science, Chiba University, Chiba 271, Japan; Department of Regional Environmental Science, Osaka Prefecture University, Osaka 593, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Kim, Y.H., Department of Agricultural Machinery Engineering, Chonbuk National University, Chonju 560-756, South Korea; Kozai, T., Department of Bioproduction Science, Chiba University, Chiba 271, Japan; Kubota, C., Department of Bioproduction Science, Chiba University, Chiba 271, Japan; Kitaya, Y., Department of Regional Environmental Science, Osaka Prefecture University, Osaka 593, Japan
Abstract: A wind tunnel consisting two air flow conditioners with polycarbonate pipes, a plant growth room, a suction fan and a fan controller, and fluorescent lamps, was newly designed to investigate the interactions between the growth of plug seedlings (plugs) under artificial light and their physical environment. Measurements showed a uniformity in the vertical profiles of air current speed at the middle and rear regions of plug trays in wind tunnel. Maximum air temperature was often observed near the top of a stand of plugs. Since Richardson number was ranged from -0.07 to +0.01, the atmosphere over a stand of plugs in wind tunnel was in an unstable or near-neutral stability state. Eddy diffusivity (KM) at air current speed of 0.9 m s-1 was about two times as many as that at air current speed of 0.3 m s-1. (K M) at the rear region was 1.6 to 23.1 % lower than that at the middle region. The wind tunnel developed in this study would be useful to investigate the effects of air current speed on the microclimates over and inside a stand of plugs and to collect basic data for a large-scale plug production under artificial light in a semi-closed ecological system.
Author Keywords: Air current speed profiles; Artificial light; Eddy diffusivity; Plug seedlings; Richardson number; Wind tunnel

Authors: King Geoffrey P., Bernstein Neil J., Coleman Robert B., Prince Joseph, Sherman Alan
Title: Impact of recently promulgated environmental regulations on petroleum refinery operations and expansions and Title V strategy development
Source title: Proceedings of the Air & Waste Management Association's Annual Meeting & Exhibition
Authors with affiliations: King, Geoffrey P.; Bernstein, Neil J.; Coleman, Robert B.; Prince, Joseph; Sherman, Alan
Abstract: Since the Clean Air Act Amendments (CAAA) were signed into law in 1990, the regulated community has had to cope with the difficulty and cost of complying with the Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA's) expanding list of regulations. Petroleum refiners need to be especially sensitive to these new regulations. The industry will have to pay special attention to the following programs, promulgated under the Act: Title V Operating Permit Program; Oxygenated and Reformulated Gasoline Program; Volatile Organic Compound (VOC) Emission Limitations for Refinery Wastewater Treatment Systems (Subpart QQQ); Maximum Achievable Control Technology (MACT) Requirements for Refineries and the Hazardous Organic NESHAP (HON) Rule; Benzene National Emission Standards for Hazardous Air Pollutants (NESHAP); and the Early Reduction Program. Enterprising refinery owners and operators are learning to use the regulations to be cost competitive in a highly regulated environment. Many of these requirements and the associated deadlines will come into effect during the next five years. The Clean Air Act (CAA) is only one of several laws that will significantly impact petroleum refiners throughout the next twenty years. Recently promulgated Resource Conservation and Recovery Act (RCRA) regulations are already affecting refinery operations. This paper will review the impact of recently promulgated regulations on refinery operations and future expansions and the need to address these issues in the Title V Operating Permit Application. It will provide suggestions for refinery operators on how to comply with the new regulations while maintaining normal refinery operations.
Index Keywords: Air pollution control; Costs; Industrial management; Laws and legislation; Petroleum refineries; Clean air act; Operating permit application; Resource conservation and recovery act; Environmental protection

Authors: Kingston-Smith A.H., Pollock C.J.
Title: Tissue level localization of acid invertase in leaves: An hypothesis for the regulation of carbon export
Affiliations: Inst. of Grass. and Environ. Res., Plas Gogerddan, Aberystwyth, Dyfed SY23 3EB, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Kingston-Smith, A.H., Inst. of Grass. and Environ. Res., Plas Gogerddan, Aberystwyth, Dyfed SY23 3EB, United Kingdom; Pollock, C.J., Inst. of Grass. and Environ. Res., Plas Gogerddan, Aberystwyth, Dyfed SY23 3EB, United Kingdom
Abstract: Photoassimilate produced by mature leaves is usually loaded into the phloem as sucrose. Transport of sucrose from the mesophyll cells to the phloem might involve an apoplastic step or be entirely symplastic, depending on species. Acid invertase occurs as both soluble and cell-wall-bound forms and has been detected in mature leaves. However, the ability of this enzyme to act as a regulator of carbon export and storage depends on whether it occurs either in the sucrose transport path (which could decrease export), or is located within the mesophyll cells (potentially resulting in intracellular futile cycling between sucrose synthesis in the cytoplasm and hydrolysis in the vacuole). Tissue-level localization of acid invertase was investigated by tissue printing, which establishes protein distribution within a leaf. Antiserum was raised against a synthetic peptide corresponding to a region close to the active site of acid invertase. Tissue prints from Pisum sativum L. and Hordeum vulgare L. showed invertase to be located in the vascular regions, which was not observed in Fuchsia hybrida L. This corresponds to differences in the presence of oligosaccharides in leaf extracts and in the pattern of plasmodesmatal connections between mesophyll cells and the vasculature. We hypothesize that the location of acid invertase activity is implicated in species-specific differences in sucrose and oligosaccharide metabolism.
Author Keywords: Acid invertase; Compartmentation; Localization; Oligosaccharide; Sucrose
Index Keywords: Fuchsia hybrid cultivar; Hordeum; Hordeum vulgare subsp. vulgare; Pisum sativum; Sativum

Authors: Kirchstetter T.W., Singer B.C., Harley R.A., Kendall G.R., Ghan W.
Title: Impact of oxygenated gasoline use on California light-duty vehicle emissions
Affiliations: Department of Civil Engineering, University of California, Berkeley, CA 94720-1710, United States; Technical Services Division, Bay Area Air Qual. Mgmt. District, 939 Ellis Street, San Francisco, CA 94109, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kirchstetter, T.W., Department of Civil Engineering, University of California, Berkeley, CA 94720-1710, United States; Singer, B.C., Department of Civil Engineering, University of California, Berkeley, CA 94720-1710, United States; Harley, R.A., Department of Civil Engineering, University of California, Berkeley, CA 94720-1710, United States; Kendall, G.R., Technical Services Division, Bay Area Air Qual. Mgmt. District, 939 Ellis Street, San Francisco, CA 94109, United States; Ghan, W., Technical Services Division, Bay Area Air Qual. Mgmt. District, 939 Ellis Street, San Francisco, CA 94109, United States
Abstract: Light-duty vehicle emissions were measured at the Caldecott Tunnel in August and October 1994. In the interval between these two periods, the average oxygen content of gasoline sold in the San Francisco Bay area increased from 0.3 to 2.0% by weight. Compared to the August (low-oxygenate) sampling period, measured pollutant emission rates during the October (high- oxygenate) sampling period for CO and VOC decreased by 21 ± 7 and 18 ± 10%, respectively, while NO(x) emissions showed no significant change. Formaldehyde emissions increased by 13 ± 6%, acetaldehyde emissions did not change significantly, and benzene emissions decreased by 25 ± 17%. Speciated VOC emission profiles show that the use of oxygenated gasoline resulted in higher MTBE and lower aromatic hydrocarbon emissions, higher isobutene, and lower aromatic aldehydes. The normalized reactivity of NMOG emissions did not change significantly between the low-oxygenate and high-oxygenate sampling periods. VOC exhaust speciation profiles for vehicles operating in the hot- stabilized mode at the Caldecott Tunnel match the speciation profile for cold-start emissions from new vehicles as measured in the Auto/Oil program. California's motor vehicle emission factor model, EMFAC7F, accurately predicts the VOC/NO(x) ratio measured at the Caldecott Tunnel in August, but underpredicts the observed CO/NO(x) ratio by a factor of 1.5-2.2 over the range of vehicle speeds observed at the tunnel.
Index Keywords: gasoline; air pollution; air quality; air sampling; article; car; environmental monitoring; exhaust gas; oil industry; united states; emission rate; oxygenated gasoline; vehicle emission; USA, California, San Francisco, Caldecott Tunnel

Authors: Kitayama J., Sawada K., Takahama H., Shinya T.
Title: Concept and actual state of developing environmental conservation forests at Oita works
Affiliations: Oita Works; Umesan Co., Ltd.; Nishinosu Kankyo Co., Ltd.
Authors with affiliations: Kitayama, J., Oita Works; Sawada, K., Umesan Co., Ltd.; Takahama, H., Oita Works; Shinya, T., Nishinosu Kankyo Co., Ltd.
Abstract: The Oita Works of Nippon Steel has been revegetating its site by ecological techniques since the beginning of its construction. Old forests in Oita were investigated and species suited for the local climate were planted to produce "native woods" at Oita Works. Twenty-five years after the start of planting, these native woods cover 1.05 million square meters and total about 800,000 trees along and within the boundaries of Oita Works. These woods play an important role as a symbol of environmental conservation and coexistence with the local community. The green tracts of land at Oita Works are the result of companywide ecological efforts and will continued to be developed and cared for as local woods.

Authors: Kittrell J.R., Quinlan C.W., Zimmermann E.K.
Title: Pentane emissions control by photocatalytic technology in the expandable polystyrene industry
Source title: Proceedings of the Air & Waste Management Association's Annual Meeting & Exhibition
Authors with affiliations: Kittrell, J.R.; Quinlan, C.W.; Zimmermann, E.K.
Abstract: Expandable polystyrene (EPS) is the raw material for a wide array of consumer and industrial products. Products based on EPS find application in industries as diverse as food service, packaging, and commercial and residential construction. Production of EPS is forecast to increase as new applications are exploited in the construction industry. In the processing of EPS, pentane is released, causing volatile organic compound (VOC) emissions. Control of VOC emissions from EPS operations is essential for compliance with Federal, state, and local air quality regulations. However, EPS applications pose an emissions control challenge due to the need for 99+% destruction efficiency, and the presence of intermittent releases, high humidity ineffluent streams, and variable pentane concentrations. KSE's AIR Process a photocatalytic oxidation technology, effectively manages VOC emissions for the EPS industry. The process has been demonstrated to effect complete destruction of pentane emissions without formation of unwanted by-products, even at the elevated concentrations encountered in the EPS industry. Simple control of ultraviolet (UV) light enables effective management of intermittent operations and the highly variable VOC concentrations. Unique system features provide excellent reliability and enable economic control of emissions at strategic locations within the EPS plant. Emissions control requirements for the EPS industry are described. Emissions control data and engineering studies on the application of the AIR Process to the EPS industry illustrate the efficacy of the technology in this service. Comparisons with alternative technologies for emissions control are presented which highlight the competitive advantages of the features and economics of the photocatalytic technology for emissions control in the EPS industry.
Index Keywords: Air pollution control equipment; Air quality; Economics; Hydrocarbons; Laws and legislation; Photochemical reactions; Polystyrenes; Reliability; Volatile organic compounds; Air quality regulations; Expandable polystyrene industry; Pentane emissions control; Photocatalytic technology; Air pollution control

Authors: Klabbers J.H.G., Swart R.J., Janssen R., Vellinga P., Van Ulden A.P.
Title: Climate science and climate policy: Improving the science/policy interface
Source title: Mitigation and Adaptation Strategies for Global Change
Affiliations: Klabbers Management & Policy Consultancy (KMPC), Bemmel, Netherlands; National Institute of Public Health and Environmental Protection (RIVM), Netherlands; Institute for Environmental Studies/Free University of Amsterdam (IVM), Amsterdam, Netherlands; Royal Netherlands Meteorological Institute (KNMI), De Bitt, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Klabbers, J.H.G., Klabbers Management & Policy Consultancy (KMPC), Bemmel, Netherlands; Swart, R.J., National Institute of Public Health and Environmental Protection (RIVM), Netherlands; Janssen, R., Institute for Environmental Studies/Free University of Amsterdam (IVM), Amsterdam, Netherlands; Vellinga, P., Institute for Environmental Studies/Free University of Amsterdam (IVM), Amsterdam, Netherlands; Van Ulden, A.P., Royal Netherlands Meteorological Institute (KNMI), De Bitt, Netherlands
Abstract: The development of an international climate policy builds on national policy perspectives. These depend on the perceived risks of climate change, socioeconomic and cultural characteristics of the nations and regions involved, and the technical feasibility of policy measures. Scientific and technological research supports the policy making process about these issues. The perspectives of the scientific community and the policy makers differ and as a consequence communication is often troublesome. The construction and utilization of knowledge under such circumstances can only be effective if all parties involved engage in a continuous dialogue about causes, effects, impacts and responses. This paper describes a project carried out in the Netherlands. It has as its major objective the articulation of a variety of perceptions and positions related to climate change. As a result of the project, policy actors produced five policy options and formulated research questions. The policy options are linked in the framework of a policy life cycle. Research questions focus on the risks of climate change and on feasible social, economic, cultural and technological responses to it. As to the policy options, striving for common means appears to be more promising than pursuing shared goals and philosophies. © 1996 Kluwer Academic Publishers.
Author Keywords: Climate change; Climate policy; The netherlands

Authors: Klevens C.M., Collins M.R., Negm R., Farrar M.F., Fulton G.P., Mastronardi R.
Title: Natural Organic Matter Characterization and Treatability by Biological Activated Carbon Filtration: Croton Reservoir Case Study
Affiliations: Department of Civil Engineering, Coll. of Eng. and Physical Sciences, Kingsbury Hall, Durham, NH 03824, United States; University of New Hampshire, Coll. of Life Sci. and Agriculture, Department of Microbiology, Durham, NH 03824, United States; Metcalf and Eddy of New York, Inc., 603 42nd Street, New York, NY 10165, United States; Hazen and Sawyer, P.C., 730 Broadway, New York, NY 10003, United States; New York City Dept. Environ. P., Jerome Park Demonstration Plant, Bronx, NY 10468, United States
Authors with affiliations: Klevens, C.M., Department of Civil Engineering, Coll. of Eng. and Physical Sciences, Kingsbury Hall, Durham, NH 03824, United States; Collins, M.R., Department of Civil Engineering, Coll. of Eng. and Physical Sciences, Kingsbury Hall, Durham, NH 03824, United States; Negm, R., University of New Hampshire, Coll. of Life Sci. and Agriculture, Department of Microbiology, Durham, NH 03824, United States; Farrar, M.F., Metcalf and Eddy of New York, Inc., 603 42nd Street, New York, NY 10165, United States; Fulton, G.P., Hazen and Sawyer, P.C., 730 Broadway, New York, NY 10003, United States; Mastronardi, R., New York City Dept. Environ. P., Jerome Park Demonstration Plant, Bronx, NY 10468, United States
Abstract: Raw water filtration of the Croton Reservoir water by GAC (10 min EBCT) was compared to treatment by ozone/biological activated carbon (BAC) filtration (10 min and 5 min EBCT) which may precede the diatomaceous earth filters proposed for this water supply for New York City. Average results showed 44-57% reduction in trihalomethanes and haloacetic acids, 28-30% reduction in chlorine demand and 21-23% reduction in TOC after BAC treatment compared to removals of 14%, 8% and 14%, respectively, achieved by GAC filtration alone. The removal of BDOC was strongly related to the removal of the 'fast' biodegradable fraction. Substrate in BAC treated effluents was comprised of more slowly biodegradable compounds than were present in the raw water. The changes in dissolved organic carbon characteristics from ozonation (i.e., to more hydrophilic, smaller, less reactive compounds) were confirmed using standard NOM fractionation techniques. In general, biomass levels were heterogeneously distributed with the highest levels at the filter surface.

Authors: Klironomos J.N., Rillig M.C., Allen M.F.
Title: Below-ground microbial and microfaunal responses to Artemisia tridentata grown under elevated atmospheric CO2
Affiliations: Department of Biology, Soil Ecology and Restoration Group, San Diego State University, San Diego, CA 92182, United States; Department of Botany, University of Guelph, Guelph, Ont. N1G 2WI, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Klironomos, J.N., Department of Biology, Soil Ecology and Restoration Group, San Diego State University, San Diego, CA 92182, United States, Department of Botany, University of Guelph, Guelph, Ont. N1G 2WI, Canada; Rillig, M.C., Department of Biology, Soil Ecology and Restoration Group, San Diego State University, San Diego, CA 92182, United States; Allen, M.F., Department of Biology, Soil Ecology and Restoration Group, San Diego State University, San Diego, CA 92182, United States
Abstract: 1. Soil microbes are fed primarily by root-derived substrates, fulfil functions such as mineralization, immobilization, decomposition, pathogeneity and improvement of plant nutrition, and form the basis of the below-ground food web. Hitherto, below-ground processes have generally been monitored using a 'black-box' approach, thereby ignoring effects of global change at a finer level of resolution. We describe shifts in the activity between microbial functional groups associated with roots of Artemisia tridentata, and the influence of this change on higher trophic levels. 2. We tested the hypothesis that elevated atmospheric CO2 causes the soil community to change qualitatively. We measured the responses of several soil microbe and soil microfaunal parameters to a double-ambient CO2 concentration and nutrient additions. The soil community, as measured by those parameters, showed great changes in response to the treatments. There was a very strong interaction between elevated CO2 and the nutrient addition. 3. Under low nutrient conditions, total microbial biomass did not change under elevated atmospheric CO2, but doubled under conditions of elevated CO2 and added nutrients. As we increased the resolution of our analysis, however, results shifted. Under low nutrient conditions, mycorrhizal fungi responded positively to elevated CO2, whereas with added soil nutrients they responded negatively to the same elevated CO2 concentration. Bacteria and non-mycorrhizal fungi did not respond under the former conditions but more than doubled in biomass under conditions of elevated CO2 and added nutrients. Soil fauna was also affected by the treatments. Overall, elevated CO2 shifted carbon flow in the plant-soil system to a more mutualistic-closed, mycorrhizal-dominated system, whereas the combination of elevated CO2 and nutrient addition shifted carbon flow to a more opportunistic-open, saprobe/pathogen-dominated one. 4. This indicates that elevated atmospheric CO2 may lead to far less predictable feedback patterns than previously thought and that qualitative shifts in the soil community may be far more important than mere changes in total C sink strength.

Authors: Kobayashi K., Ohno S., Shinoda M., Toyoshima S., Nakajin S.
Title: Immunochemical distribution and immunohistochemical localization of 20β-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase in neonatal pig tissues
Source title: Journal of Steroid Biochemistry and Molecular Biology
Affiliations: Department of Biochemistry, Faculty of Pharmaceutical Sciences, Hoshi University, 2-4-41, Ebara, Shinagawa-ku, Tokyo 142, Japan; Dept. of Clinical Pharmaceutics, Faculty of Pharmaceutical Sciences, Nihon University, Funabashi-shi, Chiba 274, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Kobayashi, K., Department of Biochemistry, Faculty of Pharmaceutical Sciences, Hoshi University, 2-4-41, Ebara, Shinagawa-ku, Tokyo 142, Japan; Ohno, S., Dept. of Clinical Pharmaceutics, Faculty of Pharmaceutical Sciences, Nihon University, Funabashi-shi, Chiba 274, Japan; Shinoda, M., Department of Biochemistry, Faculty of Pharmaceutical Sciences, Hoshi University, 2-4-41, Ebara, Shinagawa-ku, Tokyo 142, Japan; Toyoshima, S., Department of Biochemistry, Faculty of Pharmaceutical Sciences, Hoshi University, 2-4-41, Ebara, Shinagawa-ku, Tokyo 142, Japan; Nakajin, S., Department of Biochemistry, Faculty of Pharmaceutical Sciences, Hoshi University, 2-4-41, Ebara, Shinagawa-ku, Tokyo 142, Japan
Abstract: Immunochemical distribution of 20β-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase (HSD) in neonatal pig tissues was investigated by Western blot analysis of the proteins reacting with anti-20β-HSD antibody. 20β-HSD was present in all organs investigated: brain, lung, thymus, submandibular gland, heart, liver, kidney, spleen, adrenal gland, testis, epididymis, prostate, vas deferens and seminal vesicle. In particular, high concentrations of 20β-HSD were detected in the testis, followed by the kidney and liver, by the [125I]-protein A binding method. Immunohistochemical localization of the enzyme was achieved in paraffin sections of the testis, kidney, liver, epididymis, and vas deferens by the streptoavidin-biotin complex method. In the testis, very strong immunostaining was found only in interstitial Leydig cells, whereas the cells in seminiferous tubules, such as Sertoli cells and spermatogenic cells, were entirely negative. In the kidney, strong immunostaining was detected in epithelial cells of Henle's loop. The immunoreactive proteins were also localized in the hepatic lobules of the liver, tall columnar cells of the ductus epididymidis of the epididymis, and mucosal epithelium cells and muscularis of the vas deferens. These observations indicate that tissue distribution of 20β-HSD is similar to that of carbonyl reductase in the human and rat. However, the specific and abundant expression of 20β-HSD in testicular Leydig cells of the neonatal pig, which are concerned with the synthesis of androgens, suggests that 20β-HSD has a very important physiological role in testicular function during the neonatal stage.

Authors: Koch F., Geiger U., Hermsen F.-G.
Title: PIFFO-piston friction force measurements during engine operation
Affiliations: FEV Motorentechnik
Authors with affiliations: Koch, F., FEV Motorentechnik; Geiger, U., FEV Motorentechnik; Hermsen, F.-G., FEV Motorentechnik
Abstract: Fuel consumption of a modern combustion engine is significantly influenced by the mechanical friction losses. Particularly in typical city driving, the reduction of the engine friction losses offers a remarkable potential in emission and fuel consumption reduction. The analysis of the engine friction distribution of modern engines shows that the piston group has a high share at total engine friction. This offers a high potential to optimize piston group friction. The paper presents results of recent research and development work in the field of the tribological system piston/piston ring/cylinder bore. © Copyright 1996 Society of Automotive Engineers, Inc.

Authors: Koenig B.E., Henderson D.K., Mokhtarian P.L.
Title: The travel and emissions impacts of telecommuting for the State of California Telecommuting Pilot Project
Source title: Transportation Research Part C: Emerging Technologies
Affiliations: Systems Applications International, San Rafael, CA 95616, United States; Institute of Transportation Studies, University of California, Davis, CA 95616, United States; Dept. of Civ. and Environ. Eng., Institute of Transportation Studies, University of California, Davis, CA 95616, United States
Authors with affiliations: Koenig, B.E., Systems Applications International, San Rafael, CA 95616, United States; Henderson, D.K., Institute of Transportation Studies, University of California, Davis, CA 95616, United States; Mokhtarian, P.L., Dept. of Civ. and Environ. Eng., Institute of Transportation Studies, University of California, Davis, CA 95616, United States
Abstract: The impacts of home-based telecommuting on travel behavior and personal vehicle emissions for participants in the State of California Telecommuting Pilot Project are analyzed using the most advanced emissions modeling tools currently available. A comparison of participants' telecommuting day travel behavior with their before-telecommuting behavior shows a 27% reduction in the number of personal vehicle trips, a 77% decrease in vehicle-miles traveled (VMT), and 39% (and 4%) decreases in the number of cold (and hot) engine starts. These decreases in travel translate into emissions reductions of: 48% for total organic gases (TOG), 64% for carbon monoxide (CO), 69% for nitrogen oxide (NOx), and 78% for paniculate matter (PM). Although the authors developed the methodology to investigate the emissions impacts of telecommuting, the analysis technique can be applied to any demand management or other transportation strategy where all of the necessary model inputs are available. An analysis of the number of personal vehicle trips and VMT partitioned into commute-related and non-commute-related purposes revealed that non-commute personal vehicle trips increased by 0.5 trips per person-day on average, whereas the non-commute VMT decreased by 5.3 miles. This important finding supports (for one indicator, the number of trips) the hypothesis that non-commute travel generation is a potential negative impact of telecommuting. This finding demonstrates the need to monitor these changes as telecommuting moves into the mainstream. In this study, however, the small increase in non-commute trips has a negligible impact compared to the overall travel and emissions savings. Copyright © 1996 Elsevier Science Ltd.

Authors: Koenig B.E., Mokhtarian P.L., Henderson D.K.
Title: Using Travel Diary Data to Estimate the Emissions Impacts of Transportation Strategies: The Puget Sound Telecommuting Demonstration Project
Source title: Journal of the Air and Waste Management Association
Affiliations: University of California, Davis, CA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Koenig, B.E., University of California, Davis, CA, United States; Mokhtarian, P.L., University of California, Davis, CA, United States; Henderson, D.K., University of California, Davis, CA, United States
Abstract: Transportation control measures are often implemented for their environmental benefits, but there is a need to quantify what benefits actually occur. Telecommuting has the potential to reduce the number of daily trips and miles traveled with personal vehicles and, consequently, the overall emissions resulting from vehicle activity. This search studies the emissions impacts of telecommuting for the participants of the Puget Sound Telecommuting Demonstration Project (PSTDP). The California Air Resources Board's emissions models, EMFAC7F and BURDEN7F, are used to estimate the emissions on telecommuting days and non-telecommuting days, based on travel diaries completed by program participants. This study, among the first of its kind, represents the most sophisticated application of emissions models to travel diary data. Analysis of the travel diary data and the emissions model output supports the hypothesis that telecommuting has beneficial transportation and air quality impacts. The most important results are that telecommuting decreases the number of daily trips (by 30%), the vehicle-miles traveled (VMT) (by 63%), and the number of cold starts (by 44%), especially those taking place in early morning. These reductions are shown to have a large effect on daily emissions, with a 50% to 60% decrease in pollutants generated by a telecommuter's personal vehicle use on a telecommuting day. These net savings are almost entirely due to the elimination of commute trips, as non-commute trips increased by 0.33 trips per person-day (9% of the total trips), and the non-commute VMT increased by 2.2 miles. Overall reduc- tions in travel and emissions of this magnitude are observed because the telecommuters in this sample are long-distance commuters, with commutes twice as long as the regional average. However, even as telecommuting adoption moves into the mainstream, its net impacts are still expected to be beneficial— a reduction in VMT and in emissions. It is important to note that when the level of telecommuting is considered (that is, the percentage of work days that employees actually telecommute), the weekly savings are a much smaller proportion of total weekday travel. Also, these findings represent average per-capita reductions; the aggregate (or overall, regionwide) impacts are determined by scaling these reductions by the number of program participants. Thus, the aggregate effectiveness of telecommuting must take into account the number of people likely to participate as telecommuters and how often they telecommute, not just the per-capita, peroccasion impacts. © 1996 Air & Waste Management Association.

Title: Three 18-Electron Tantalum(I) Compounds, TaCl(CO)2(dppe)2, [TaCl(CO)2(dppe)2]2x, and TaCl(CO)4(dppe) (dppe = 1,2-Bis(diphenylphosphino)ethane), Which Exhibit Low Levels of Paramagnetism
