Authors: Rao S.T., Zurbenko I.G., Porter P.S., Ku J.Y., Henry R.F.
Title: Dealing with the ozone non-attainment problem in the eastern United States
Source title: EM: Air and Waste Management Association's Magazine for Environmental Managers
Affiliations: University at Albany, Albany, NY, United States; University of Idaho, Idaho Falls, ID, United States; New York State Dept. Environ. C., Albany, NY, United States; Department of Atmospheric Science, University at Albany; Bureau of Air Research, New York State Dept. Environ. C., 50 Wolf Road, Albany, NY 12233, United States; Department of Epidemiology, School of Public Health at UA; Dept. of Civ. and Environ. Eng., University of Idaho, Idaho Falls, ID 83405, United States; BAR, NYSDEC
Authors with affiliations: Rao, S.T., University at Albany, Albany, NY, United States, Department of Atmospheric Science, University at Albany, Bureau of Air Research, New York State Dept. Environ. C., 50 Wolf Road, Albany, NY 12233, United States; Zurbenko, I.G., University at Albany, Albany, NY, United States, Department of Epidemiology, School of Public Health at UA; Porter, P.S., University of Idaho, Idaho Falls, ID, United States, Dept. of Civ. and Environ. Eng., University of Idaho, Idaho Falls, ID 83405, United States; Ku, J.Y., New York State Dept. Environ. C., Albany, NY, United States, BAR, NYSDEC; Henry, R.F., New York State Dept. Environ. C., Albany, NY, United States, BAR, NYSDEC
Abstract: Despite significant efforts over the past two decades to alleviate the ozone non-attainment problem, ambient ozone concentrations continue to exceed the ozone standard in many parts of the eastern United States. In this paper, we demonstrate that the observed ozone time series is comprised of deterministic and stochastic components; the deterministic part contains seasonal variation and long-term trend, superimposed upon which is the white noise process. The stochastic variations cannot be controlled. However, after separation of the white noise process, the deterministic part forms a stable basis for the examination of responses in ozone concentrations to changes in precursor emissions. Based on this examination, we argue that a reduction in the deterministic part is needed to achieve ozone compliance. The information developed in this study can then be used in conjunction with the results from photochemical models in determining the level and type of emission reductions required for ozone attainment. Currently, photochemical models are being used to simulate episodic ozone events, rather than baseline, for determining the level of emission reductions needed to achieve compliance with the ozone standard. Given the uncertainties inherent in the modeling, total reliance on absolute model predictions may be stretching the applicability of such models beyond their limits. Models are more useful when they are used as tools for directional and relative analyses than in an absolute sense.

Authors: Raper D.W., Lee D.S.
Title: Wet deposition at the sub-20 km scale in a rural upland area of England
Affiliations: Dept. of Environ. and Geogr. Sci., Manchester Metropolitan University, Manchester M1 5GD, United Kingdom; AEA Technology, Natl. Environ. Technology Centre, Culham Laboratory, Oxfordshire OX14 3DB, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Raper, D.W., Dept. of Environ. and Geogr. Sci., Manchester Metropolitan University, Manchester M1 5GD, United Kingdom; Lee, D.S., AEA Technology, Natl. Environ. Technology Centre, Culham Laboratory, Oxfordshire OX14 3DB, United Kingdom
Abstract: A network of 10 bulk precipitation collectors was established in an upland region of northern England to examine the small-scale variability of precipitation composition in a rural area. Significant spatial variability was shown for non sea-salt sulphate, calcium and hydrogen ion concentrations. Although nitrate concentrations did not show significant variability, a coherent gradient across the study area was observed. The large variability of calcium ion concentration across the area was related to limestone quarrying, which is prevalent in the south of the study area. Calcareous wind-blown soil may have also made a minor contribution to the abundance of calcium in the rain-water samples. It is likely, however, that a large fraction of the calcium was dry deposited to the funnels of the collectors in the form of particles. The network was not designed to study orographic enhancement of deposition, but it is suggested that this mechanism, along with wind-drift of scavenged cap-cloud droplets, cannot explain the spatial variation in ion concentrations. It is speculated that the variability in non-sea-salt sulphate concentrations may also be partially explained by reaction of CaCO3 particles deposited to the funnels of the collectors with SO2. Critical load exceedances in terms of deposited acidity from non-sea-salt sulphate were calculated using different spatially resolved deposition data. A better estimate of deposition in the study area was achieved by combining rainfall concentration data from the national network with the 5 km rainfall field, than the current methodology used for mapping of U.K. deposition which utilises a 20 km rainfall field. However, 20 km is considered to be the minimum resolution at which a procedure for parameterising orographic enhancement can be incorporated. Deposition and critical load exceedances in 2005 were calculated using a long-range transport model and significant improvements in the protection of soils were predicted from the projected emissions reductions.
Author Keywords: Critical loads; Small-scale variability; Wet deposition
Index Keywords: calcium ion; limestone; nitrate; proton; rain; sulfate; air pollution; article; geographic distribution; pH; priority journal; rural area; United Kingdom; precipitation chemistry; precipitation collection network; rainfall concentration data; subgrid rainfall field; wet deposition; UK, England

Authors: Rau B.
Title: Influencing HIV / AIDS policy in Kenya: NGOs build consensus. Policy profile.
Authors with affiliations: Rau, B.
Abstract: Despite widespread public awareness in Kenya about the HIV/AIDS epidemic, most policy makers in government and other sectors as of 1994 chose not to adopt and implement HIV/AIDS prevention and control policies. Since then, however, the HIV/AIDS policy situation has changed in many ways. Officials now hope to see practical policies adopted and implemented. The government is preparing a national HIV/AIDS policy and has sought input from a broad range of technical, legal, ethical, and policy opinion makers. With support from the AIDS Control and Prevention (AIDSCAP) Project, MAP International facilitated policy-oriented discussions among church leaders, while the Kenya AIDS Nongovernmental Organizations Consortium solicited the experiences and views of local constituents during a series of district and provincial policy workshops. These and other efforts to shape HIV/AIDS policy include improvements in the policy climate in Kenya, better mechanisms for strengthening HIV/AIDS prevention and care, and some specific changes in policy. Policy development, the policy climate, improved mechanisms, and policy change are discussed.

Authors: Raulin F., Bruston P.
Title: Photochemical growing of complex organics in planetary atmospheres
Affiliations: LISA, URA-CNRS 1404, Université Paris 12 and 7, 61 Ave. du Gen. de Gaulle, F-94010 Créteil Cedex, France
Authors with affiliations: Raulin, F., LISA, URA-CNRS 1404, Université Paris 12 and 7, 61 Ave. du Gen. de Gaulle, F-94010 Créteil Cedex, France; Bruston, P., LISA, URA-CNRS 1404, Université Paris 12 and 7, 61 Ave. du Gen. de Gaulle, F-94010 Créteil Cedex, France
Abstract: UV induced syntheses of organic compounds from the main atmospheric constituents can be a very important source of organics in a given planetary environment provided the atmosphere is in a reduced state. The evolution of a CO2 rich medium only produces very low yields of formaldehyde and related oxygenated compounds. Considering a CO rich atmosphere, the photochemical yield of O-organics formation is much higher, when the synthesis of N-organics remains difficult. The most favourable atmosphere as far as photochemical organic synthesis is concerned is a CH4 rich milieu.. The photochemical evolution of such a CH4 atmosphere under UV irradiation leads to a chain of various organics, the complexity of which increases together with the number of pathways involved in their formation. Their complexity also closely correlates with their UV photoabsorption spectrum : the more complex they are, the more shifted is their UV spectrum toward the visible range. Direct photodissociation of methane requires UV photon of wavelengths shorter than about 145 nm. It mainly produces ethane which absorbs UV at wavelengths shorter than about 160 nm, and acetylene, that presents an absorption spectrum extending up to 200 nm. This shift still continuously increases with further increase in number of C atoms. Unsaturated hydrocarbons with 4 and more C atoms have UV absorption characteristics including noticeable band structures in the 250-300 nm range. This trend has very important implication in the photochemical behaviour of a CH4-rich planetary atmosphere, as it induces many catalytic processes. The occurrence of such processes is closely related to vertical atmospheric and energy deposition profiles. Titan provides a very good example of such a UV-directed organic atmospheric chemistry. Index Keywords: absorption spectrum; atmospheric chemistry; carbon dioxide; gas phase; methane; organic compound; ultraviolet absorption

Authors: Rayner R.J.
Title: The palaeoclimate of the Karoo: Evidence from plant fossils
Affiliations: B.P.I. Palaeontology, University of the Witwatersrand, P.O. Box 179, Wits 2050, South Africa
Authors with affiliations: Rayner, R.J., B.P.I. Palaeontology, University of the Witwatersrand, P.O. Box 179, Wits 2050, South Africa
Abstract: The common and conspicuous Karoo fossil floras flourished in what appears to be climatically disadvantageous conditions, as southern Gondwana lay within the Antarctic Circle throughout much of the Permian. Most previous climatic reconstructions suggest a cold-temperate climate. Plant structures are sensitive to environmental conditions, particularly climate, and may be used to predict these conditions. Large Glossopteris leaves dominate fossil plant assemblages, and considerable deposits of coal were laid down at this time. Quantitative analyses of fossil leaves from three coeval localities indicate that the climate prevailing at the time of the burial of these Glossopteris floras was seasonal, with summer conditions extremely favourable for plant growth, comparable to tropical regions today, and winters that were also correspondingly warmer than has previously been suggested. © 1995 Elsevier Science B.V. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Glossopteris; Gondwana; Karoo; palaeoclimate; Permian; plant fossil; Africa

Authors: Reading K.
Title: A study of the clean-up activity of a high-performance diesel fuel detergent in IDI engines
Affiliations: Shell Research and Technology Centre
Authors with affiliations: Reading, K., Shell Research and Technology Centre
Abstract: Almost all published work involving injector nozzle cleanliness has been performed by means of keep-clean tests. Another area of interest in the performance of detergents is that of clean-up, which is the ability of a detergent to remove excessive deposits built up in previous service. A study is now reported in which the degree of clean-up is established for a modern commercial detergent used in a low-sulphur diesel fuel. Measurements are presented from a bench engine and also from road vehicles operated under controlled urban driving conditions. Substantial clean-up is demonstrated using detergent treat-rates representative of modern formulation technology, regaining the state of cleanliness that provides optimum performance of the injection equipment. The fouling levels after clean-up are comparable with the results of keep-clean tests, run under identical conditions. Accumulated driving distance and fuel usage to provide this clean-up effect are also discussed. The reductions in fouling are then used to predict a reduction in vehicle exhaust emissions and better fuel economy, by comparison with the results of previous studies. © 1996 Society of Automotive Engineers, Inc.
Index Keywords: Diesel engines; Diesel fuels; Fuels; Soaps (detergents); Area of interest; Clean-up activities; Driving conditions; Driving distance; Identical conditions; Injection equipment; Optimum performance; Vehicle exhaust emissions; Fuel economy

Authors: Reason C.J.C.
Title: Stability dependent parameterisations of vertical mixing in ocean general circulation models
Affiliations: School of Earth Sciences, University of Melbourne, Parkville, Vic. 3052, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Reason, C.J.C., School of Earth Sciences, University of Melbourne, Parkville, Vic. 3052, Australia
Abstract: Parameterisations of mixing induced through shear instability, internal wave breaking, and double diffusion are investigated in simulations of ocean climate using a global ocean general circulation model (OGCM). Focus is placed on the sensitivity of the large scale circulation, water mass formation and transport of heat as measures of the model's ability to represent current climate. The model resolution is typical of OGCMs being coupled to atmospheric. GCMs in climate models and the parameterisations investigated are all computationally inexpensive enough to allow for integrations on long time scales. Under the assumption of constant vertical eddy coefficients (the control case), the model climatology displays acceptable values of North Atlantic Deep Water formation, Antarctic Circumpolar Current (ACC) transport, and Indonesian through-flow but an excessively deep and diffuse pycnocline structure with weak stratification in the deep ocean. It is found that various circulation and water mass properties are sensitive to the choice of parameterisation of vertical mixing and that determining a scheme which works satisfactorily over all regions (tropical, mid-latitude, and polar) of the domain is not straightforward. Parameterisations of internal wave breaking or upper ocean shear instability lead to some improvements in the model water mass formation. ACC and poleward heat transport when compared to the control case whereas parameterisations of double diffusive processes did not. Based on these and other results, various recommendations are made for mixing parameterisations in ocean climate models.

Authors: Recchia Christopher, Dainoff Alexander S., Albanese Vincent M.
Title: Systemwide NOx control strategy for CRRA
Source title: Proceedings of the Air & Waste Management Association's Annual Meeting & Exhibition
Authors with affiliations: Recchia, Christopher; Dainoff, Alexander S.; Albanese, Vincent M.
Abstract: In an effort to meet Connecticut requirements for NOx emissions, Connecticut Resources Recovery Authority has installed a commercial SNCR unit on one of their units. The Nalco Fuel Tech NOxOUT_SNCR Process was installed on one of three 676 TPD RDF (Refuse-Derived Fuel) incinerators located in Hartford, Connecticut. The program was designed for significant NOx reductions on the unit to meet a state-imposed requirement and to also allow overcontrol of NOx for generation of NOx emission reduction 'credits' for use at other CRRA facilities or elsewhere. These units each have a CE VU 40 designed boiler with a hydrograte designed to burn RDF and Coal. The SNCR system was designed to provide between 35 and 40% NOx reduction from 90 to 100% MCR while firing either RDF or Coal. The NOxOUT_ system was installed on a turnkey basis by Nalco Fuel Tech and included all required reagent storage and handling equipment, metering and distribution modules, and injectors. The System also included a separate PLC control module to control the process by utilizing the existing CEM and boiler operating readings from the plant's control system. The system was designed with two levels of injection in the furnace with independent level control to automatically maintain targeted NOx level with fluctuating load and operating conditions. This paper outlines the details of the process from the design of the system and process parameters to the ongoing results of how the system contributes to overall NOx reduction and control strategy of the Authority.
Index Keywords: Laws and legislation; Nitrogen oxides; Programmable logic controllers; Refuse derived fuels; Refuse incinerators; Connecticut resources recovery authority; Emission control; Industrial emissions

Authors: Recher H.F., Majer J.D., Ganesh S.
Title: Seasonality of canopy invertebrate communities in eucalypt forests of eastern and western Australia
Affiliations: Department of Ecosystem Management, University of New England, Armidale, NSW 2350, Australia; School of Environmental Biology, Curtin University of Technology, PO Box U1987, Perth, WA 6001, Australia; Department of Statistics, Massey University, Private Bag 11222, Palmerston North, New Zealand
Authors with affiliations: Recher, H.F., Department of Ecosystem Management, University of New England, Armidale, NSW 2350, Australia; Majer, J.D., School of Environmental Biology, Curtin University of Technology, PO Box U1987, Perth, WA 6001, Australia; Ganesh, S., Department of Statistics, Massey University, Private Bag 11222, Palmerston North, New Zealand
Abstract: Chemical knockdown procedures were used to sample canopy arthropods at 3 month intervals over 1 year at two sites, one in eastern Australia and the other in western Australia. Samples were taken from narrow-leaved ironbark, Eucalyptus crebra, and grey box, Eucalyptus moluccana, in the east and from jarrah, Eucalyptus marginata, and marri, Eucalyptus calophylla, in the west. Arthropods were more abundant on trees in eastern Australia and exhibited different seasonal patterns from those in the west. Members of different functional groups exhibited different seasonal patterns, with some herbivorous groups responding to times of leaf production, decomposers and fungus feeders responding to high moisture availability, and predators/parasites responding to the abundance of food items. Seasonal variability was slightly higher in the west, possibly reflecting the greater seasonal amplitude in rainfall. In the eastern forest, proportionately more taxa peaked in spring or summer and declined to minimum numbers in winter. In the western forest several taxa attained peak numbers in autumn, winter or spring, while others declined to minimum values in winter or summer. The phenological patterns of canopy arthropods appear to be linked to the condition of the host plant and/or to climatic factors. Comparison of the western Australian data to those from a second year of sampling at a time when rainfall was greater and fell later into the season indicated that variability in arthropod numbers between years can be as great as that between seasons. Implications of the variability in seasonal and annual patterns of canopy invertebrate communities are discussed in relation to the need for long-term sampling and in relation to evaluating the impact of disturbance on forest communities.
Author Keywords: Arthropods; Canopy; Eucalyptus; Seasonality

Authors: Reighard T.S., Olesik S.V.
Title: Comparison of the extraction of phenolic and nitroaromatic pollutants using supercritical and enhanced-fluidity liquid methanol-CO2 mixtures
Affiliations: Department of Chemistry, Ohio State University, 120 W. 18th, Columbus, OH 43210, United States
Authors with affiliations: Reighard, T.S., Department of Chemistry, Ohio State University, 120 W. 18th, Columbus, OH 43210, United States; Olesik, S.V., Department of Chemistry, Ohio State University, 120 W. 18th, Columbus, OH 43210, United States
Abstract: The extraction of eleven phenols and nitroaromatics from an octadecyl polysiloxane stationary phase material is investigated using both supercritical fluid and enhanced-fluidity liquid conditions. Carbon dioxide and extraction fluid mixtures consisting of 10 and 20 mol% methanol in CO2 are tested at 25, 45 and 65°C. Characteristic properties of the matrix, analytes and extraction fluids are examined in order to explain trends and controlling factors in extraction yields. As expected, the higher solvent strength of the methanol-CO2 mixtures greatly reduces the volume and time required for efficient extraction compared to CO2 alone. The effect of temperature is markedly less important than composition for the mixtures and matrix studied and the state of the extraction fluid, either liquid or supercritical, is irrelevant for the majority of analytes. The enhanced-fluidity liquid technique appears to be a viable alternative to supercritical fluid extraction for the extraction of polar analytes from more complex matrices.

Authors: Reinhardt Hans-Wolf, Dinku Abebe
Title: Measuring the gas permeability of cover concrete by means of high overpressure [Ermittlung der Gasdurchlaessigkeit der Betonrandzone mit hohem Ueberdruck]
Source title: Betonwerk und Fertigteil-Technik/Concrete Precasting Plant and Technology
Authors with affiliations: Reinhardt, Hans-Wolf; Dinku, Abebe
Abstract: The durability of concrete is a function of concrete properties, both, at the fresh and hardened state. It depends mainly on the nature of the pores, pore size distribution and crack formation in concrete. Consequently, the classical concrete mix design approach based on compressive strength criteria do not necessarily produce durable concrete. Proper concrete mix design accompanied by good material selection, adequate supervision during concreting and curing is known to be very important in an effort to produce durable concrete. It has been generally accepted that the durability properties of concrete can be basically studied using permeability, diffusivity and sorptivity measurements, since these parameters depend on the actual pore structure of the concrete. In the recent years, however, assessment of concrete performance using gas permeability measurements of concrete are given more importance due to the fact that gas permeability measurements take short time, produce repeatable test results provided appropriate test method is chosen and can be made either in situ or in the laboratory without significant destruction. Meanwhile, the tendencies of current research results are aimed at relating gas permeability coefficients to performance properties of concrete, such as depth of carbonation and sorptivity, in order to make a prognosis of durability. Numerous gas permeability test methods are available in practice and are discussed elsewhere [1], [2], [3]. The design and test procedure of these test methods vary widely: some of the methods are designed mainly to be used in the laboratory condition, e.g. [4], [5], while others can be used on sites as well [6], [7]. In most of the cases, they require specimen conditioning before testing (and are mainly destructive) and therefore test results do not represent the actual material property. In this report gas permeability of concrete specimens as measured by the overpressure method [3], [8] will be presented and its relation to other concrete properties will be discussed.
Index Keywords: Durability; Gases; High pressure effects; Mechanical permeability; Mechanical variables measurement; Nitrogen; Overpressure test method; Permeability measurement; Concretes

Authors: Remy P.M., Boissenin Y.M., Molière M.M.
Title: Benefits of MS 6001B gas turbine in cogeneration: The UEM power plant case
Source title: Journal of Engineering for Gas Turbines and Power
Affiliations: Usine d’Electricité de Metz (UEM), Metz, France; European Gas Turbines, Beltort, France
Authors with affiliations: Remy, P.M., Usine d’Electricité de Metz (UEM), Metz, France; Boissenin, Y.M., European Gas Turbines, Beltort, France; Molière, M.M., European Gas Turbines, Beltort, France
Abstract: Long before the neologism “Cogeneration” was coined (around 1978), UEM’s Chambière Power Plant—which dates back to the turn of the century—was already supplying the city of Metz, east of France, with combined heat and power. In 1992, Chambiere experienced a major turning point in its history with the installation of a new unit based on one MS 600IB “Heavy Duty” gas turbine. This model, rated 38 MWe-ISO and burning natural gas or fuel oil, has become the core of a new cogeneration unit exhibiting outstanding performance: efficiency higher than 80 percent (LHV) providing a 20 percent energy saving in comparison to a conventional plant low pollutant emissions (NOx, CO, HC) and low contribution to the greenhouse effect (CO2). The gas turbine has been equipped with two steam injection devices, for DeNOx and power augmentation, respectively, resulting in a very flexible system. After describing the power plant and giving its main achievements in the fields of energy and emissions, the paper briefly presents several improvements intended to protect both the turbine and the environment. © 1996 by ASME.

Authors: Renström E., Eliasson L., Bokvist K., Rorsman P.
Title: Cooling inhibits exocytosis in single mouse pancreatic B-cells by suppression of granule mobilization
Affiliations: Department of Islet Cell Physiology, Symbion Science Park, Novo Nordisk A/S, Fruebjergvej 3, DK-2100 Copenhagen, Denmark; Dept. of Physiology and Pharmacology, Division of Biophysics, Medicinaregatan 11, S-41390 Göteborg, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: Renström, E., Department of Islet Cell Physiology, Symbion Science Park, Novo Nordisk A/S, Fruebjergvej 3, DK-2100 Copenhagen, Denmark; Eliasson, L., Dept. of Physiology and Pharmacology, Division of Biophysics, Medicinaregatan 11, S-41390 Göteborg, Sweden; Bokvist, K., Department of Islet Cell Physiology, Symbion Science Park, Novo Nordisk A/S, Fruebjergvej 3, DK-2100 Copenhagen, Denmark; Rorsman, P., Department of Islet Cell Physiology, Symbion Science Park, Novo Nordisk A/S, Fruebjergvej 3, DK-2100 Copenhagen, Denmark
Abstract: 1. The mechanisms by which cooling inhibits insulin secretion were investigated by capacitance measurements of exocytosis in single mouse pancreatic B-cells maintained in short-term tissue culture. 2. A reduction of the bath temperature from 34 to 24°C produced a gradual inhibition of exocytosis. Inhibition of exocytosis was use dependent rather than time dependent. The steady-state inhibition amounted to 90%, which was paralleled by a 30% reduction of the peak Ca2+ current. 3. The Q10 values (between 27 and 37°C) for inhibition of exocytosis and the peak Ca2+ current amplitude were determined as > 5 and 1.6, respectively. From the temperature dependence of exocytosis, an energy of activation was estimated as 145 kJ mol-1. 4. Suppression of exocytosis was not the result of a reduction of Ca2+ influx. When the Ca2+ currents were blocked by 30% (comparable to that produced by cooling) by using a low concentration of Co2+, exocytosis was reduced by < 25%. 5. Elevation of cytoplasmic free Ca2+, by photorelease of 'caged' Ca2+ from Ca2+-nitrophenyl-EGTA preloaded into the B-cell, was equally effective at eliciting exocytosis at 24 and 34°C. 6. Cooling produced 70% inhibition of exocytosis evoked by infusion of Ca2+ through the recording electrode. Omission of either MgATP or cAMP from the electrode solution resulted in a comparable reduction of exocytosis. Cooling had no additional inhibitory effect when exocytosis was already suppressed by removal of cytoplasmic MgATP. 7. Our data indicate that exocytosis of granules already docked beneath the membrane is little affected by cooling in the B-cell. Instead, the high overall temperature sensitivity of insulin secretion arises because the replenishment of the readily releasable pool is temperature dependent.
Index Keywords: adenosine triphosphate magnesium; calcium ion; cyclic AMP; insulin; animal cell; article; calcium current; calcium transport; cell granule; cooling; exocytosis; insulin release; mouse; nonhuman; pancreas islet beta cell; priority journal; temperature dependence

Authors: Rice Glenn E., Lyon Brad F., Keating Martha
Title: Predicted fate and transport of mercury emitted from utility boilers in the local atmosphere
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: United States Environmental, Protection Agency, Cincinnati, United States
Authors with affiliations: Rice, Glenn E., United States Environmental, Protection Agency, Cincinnati, United States; Lyon, Brad F., United States Environmental, Protection Agency, Cincinnati, United States; Keating, Martha, United States Environmental, Protection Agency, Cincinnati, United States
Abstract: In 1990 it was estimated that utility boilers accounted for approximately 21% of anthropogenic mercury emitted to the atmosphere in the United States (U.S.). To characterize the utility industry a series of model plants were developed. Using a modified version of the COMPDEP air model, the fate of the mercury emissions from the model plant developed to represent large coal-burning boilers was predicted. Estimated annual air concentrations at a hypothetical site 2.5 Km downwind from the model plant were 0.001 ng/m3 and the estimated annual mercury deposition rate was less than 10 ug/m2/yr. Of the mercury emitted from this model plant, less than 5% percent is predicted to deposit within 50 Km of the emission source. The mercury remaining in the atmosphere is thought to become part of a regional and eventually global mass of atmospheric mercury.
Index Keywords: Air pollution; Atmospheric composition; Coal fired boilers; Mathematical models; Mercury (metal); Anthropogenic mercury; Atmospheric mercury; Particulate emissions

Authors: Richardson D.M., Cowling R.M., Lamont B.B.
Title: Non-linearities, synergisms and plant extinctions in South African fynbos and Australian kwongan
Affiliations: Institute for Plant Conservation, Botany Department, University of Cape Town, Private Bag, Rondebosch 7700, South Africa; School of Environmental Biology, Curtin University of Technology, PO Box U1987, Perth, WA 6001, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Richardson, D.M., Institute for Plant Conservation, Botany Department, University of Cape Town, Private Bag, Rondebosch 7700, South Africa; Cowling, R.M., Institute for Plant Conservation, Botany Department, University of Cape Town, Private Bag, Rondebosch 7700, South Africa; Lamont, B.B., School of Environmental Biology, Curtin University of Technology, PO Box U1987, Perth, WA 6001, Australia
Abstract: This paper explores the determinants of extinction of endemic plant taxa in mediterranean-climate regions in South Africa and southwestern Australia. Major threats to biodiversity in these areas include agriculture, deforestation, fragmentation, invasive alien organisms and urbanization. Case studies from the two regions show that synergisms between factors can lead to discontinuous, or non-linear, responses that have increased extinction rates (or threaten to) beyond predictions based on simple deterministic processes.

Authors: Richels R., Sturm P.
Title: The costs of CO2 emission reductions: Some insights from global analyses
Affiliations: Ener. Anal. and Planning Department, Electric Power Research Institute, 3412 Hillview Avenue, Palo Alto, CA 94303, United States
Authors with affiliations: Richels, R., Ener. Anal. and Planning Department, Electric Power Research Institute, 3412 Hillview Avenue, Palo Alto, CA 94303, United States; Sturm, P., Ener. Anal. and Planning Department, Electric Power Research Institute, 3412 Hillview Avenue, Palo Alto, CA 94303, United States
Abstract: In recent years numerous studies on the costs of CO2 emissions abatement have been published.. The majority of these efforts have been at the country level. Such studies have contributed substantially to our understanding of the costs of emissions abatement. Studies which confine emission reduction opportunities to the boundaries of a single country however have certain limitations. First, they ignore low cost abatement opportunities available elsewhere in the world. Hence, they fail to identify least cost mitigation strategies. Second, they ignore potentially important 'spill over effects' - for example, the effect of a slowdown in economic growth in one country on the prices and incomes of another. Additional insights can be gained from taking a more global perspective. Capturing the relevant interactions, however, requires a 'general equilibrium' formulation of the global economic system. Copyright © 1996. Published by Elsevier Science Ltd.
Author Keywords: CO2 emissions; Emissions abatement; General equilibrium model

Abstract: Amounts between 2.5 and 5.9% of HBr, HCl and Cl2 were added to fullerene forming benzene/oxygen/argon flat-flames burning at 75 mbar in an attempt to affect halogen substitutions in the carbon framework. The inhibition effect of HBr dramatically reduced the yield of fullerene, while it stayed in the same order of magnitude after addition of HCl or Cl2. No formation of halogenated fullerenic compounds could be detected by mass spectrometry using chemical ionization with CH4/N2O or MALDI. The measurement of bromine- and chlorine-precursor mass spectra showed the formation of a great number of bromine or chlorine containing compounds, essentially polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAH). In the case of HBr addition, only relatively small molecules could be observed because reactions with bromine atoms are thermodynamically less favourable in regions far from the burner with relatively high temperatures.

Authors: Ridgley M.A.
Title: Fair sharing of greenhouse gas burdens
Affiliations: Department of Geography, University of Hawaii at Manoa, 2424 Maile Way, Honolulu, HI 96822, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ridgley, M.A., Department of Geography, University of Hawaii at Manoa, 2424 Maile Way, Honolulu, HI 96822, United States
Abstract: This paper describes an approach to determine the relative accountability that each region and individual nation should bear in reducing atmospheric greenhouse gas. The paper argues that accountability should be based on equity and that all measures of equity for which there are backers should be used in the decision making procedure. Each equity indicator defines a different accountability profile, leading to conflicting prescriptions. Multicriterion decision making methods are seen as having high potential to help design fair compromise profiles, and a methodology is proposed and numerous methods indicated for this purpose. The methodology is illustrated by defining 11 different equity indicators and then formulating and solving a multigoal programming model to determine a compromise accountability profile for 11 multinational regions. Authors: Rigneault H., Flory F., Monneret S., Robert S., Roux L.
Title: Fluorescence of Ta2O5 thin films doped by kilo-electron-volt Er implantation: Application to microcavities
Affiliations: Laboratoire d’Optique des Surfaces et des Couches Minces, Unité Associée au Centre National de la Recherche Scientifique, Ecole Nationale Supérieure de Physique de Marseille, Domaine Universitaire de St. Jéräme, Marseille Cedex 20, Marseille, 13397, France; Ion Beam Service, 101 Z. A. Des Pradeaux, Gréasque, 13850, France
Authors with affiliations: Rigneault, H., Laboratoire d’Optique des Surfaces et des Couches Minces, Unité Associée au Centre National de la Recherche Scientifique, Ecole Nationale Supérieure de Physique de Marseille, Domaine Universitaire de St. Jéräme, Marseille Cedex 20, Marseille, 13397, France; Flory, F., Laboratoire d’Optique des Surfaces et des Couches Minces, Unité Associée au Centre National de la Recherche Scientifique, Ecole Nationale Supérieure de Physique de Marseille, Domaine Universitaire de St. Jéräme, Marseille Cedex 20, Marseille, 13397, France; Monneret, S., Laboratoire d’Optique des Surfaces et des Couches Minces, Unité Associée au Centre National de la Recherche Scientifique, Ecole Nationale Supérieure de Physique de Marseille, Domaine Universitaire de St. Jéräme, Marseille Cedex 20, Marseille, 13397, France; Robert, S., Laboratoire d’Optique des Surfaces et des Couches Minces, Unité Associée au Centre National de la Recherche Scientifique, Ecole Nationale Supérieure de Physique de Marseille, Domaine Universitaire de St. Jéräme, Marseille Cedex 20, Marseille, 13397, France; Roux, L., Ion Beam Service, 101 Z. A. Des Pradeaux, Gréasque, 13850, France
Abstract: Luminescent layers are prepared by the implantation of kilo-electron-volt Er ions into tantalum pentoxide (Ta2O5) thin films made by ion plating. The implantation fluences range from 3.3 × 1014 to 2 × 1015 ionsycm2, and the energies range from 190 to 380 keV. Refractive index, extinction coefficient, and losses on guided propagation are investigated. We show that these Er-implanted layers present an absorption as low as that of the nonimplanted films. When optically pumped with an Ar+ laser (λ 5 0.488 μm) beam, implanted films show peaked fluorescence spectra centered near 1.53 and 0.532 mm. We show that the fluorescence intensity is correlated with the intensity of the pump beam in the region where Er ions are implanted. Radiation patterns of Er ions located inside a single layer or inside a Ta2O5ySiO2 dielectric stack made by ion plating are also investigated. We show that, in any case, spontaneous emission of Er ions can be spatially controlled. © 1996 Optical Society of America.
Author Keywords: Er ion; Ion implantation; Microcavities; Spontaneous emission; Thin films

Abstract: Host plant, climate, cultural and natural mortality factors are emphasized as predominately determining regional population dynamics of Bemisia in agricultural systems. Authors: Riley W.J., Fisk W.J., Gadgil A.J.
Title: Regional and national estimates of the potential energy use, energy cost and CO2 emissions associated with radon mitigation by sub-slab depressurization
Affiliations: Civil Engineering Department, University of California, Berkeley, CA 94720, United States; Indoor Environment Program, Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, Berkeley, CA 94720, United States
Authors with affiliations: Riley, W.J., Civil Engineering Department, University of California, Berkeley, CA 94720, United States, Indoor Environment Program, Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, Berkeley, CA 94720, United States; Fisk, W.J., Indoor Environment Program, Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, Berkeley, CA 94720, United States; Gadgil, A.J., Indoor Environment Program, Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, Berkeley, CA 94720, United States
Abstract: Active sub-slab depressurization (SSD) systems are an effective means of reducing indoor radon concentrations in residential buildings. However, energy is required to operate the system fan and to heat or cool the resulting increased building ventilation. We present regional and national estimates of the energy requirements, operating expenses and CO2 emissions associated with using SSD systems at saturation (i.e. in all US homes with radon concentrations above the EPA remediation guideline and either basement or slab-on-grade construction). The primary source of uncertainty in these estimates is the impact of the SSD system on house ventilation rate. Overall, individual SSD system operating expenses are highest in the Northeast and Midwest at about $99 y-1, and lowest in the South and West at about $66 y-1. The fan consumes, on average, about 40% of the end-use energy used to operate the SSD system and accounts for about 60% of the annual expense. At saturation, regional impacts are largest in the Midwest because this area has a large number of mitigable houses and a relatively high heating load. We estimate that operating SSD systems in US houses, where it is both appropriate and possible (about 2.6 million houses), will annually consume 1.7 × 104 (6.4 × 103 to 3.9 × 104) TJ of end-use energy, cost $230 (130 to 400) million (at current energy prices), and generate 2.0 × 109 (1.2 × 109 to 3.5 × 109) kg of CO2. Passive or energy efficient radon mitigation systems currently being developed offer opportunities to substantially reduce these impacts.
Author Keywords: Active sub-slab depressurization; CO2 emissions; Cost; Energy; Residential buildings; Sub-slab ventilation
Index Keywords: Air pollution control; Carbon dioxide; Cost effectiveness; Energy utilization; Environmental impact; Gas emissions; Housing; Radon; Ventilation; Active subslab depressurization (SSD) systems; Subslab ventilation; Indoor air pollution

Authors: Ritz S.M.
Title: Remediation by natural attenuation: a state policy overview
Source title: Hazardous and Industrial Wastes - Proceedings of the Mid-Atlantic Industrial Waste Conference
Affiliations: Roy F. Weston, Inc, Morrisville, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ritz, S.M., Roy F. Weston, Inc, Morrisville, United States
Abstract: The process of natural attenuation at low levels of contaminants is discussed as a remediation method for hydrocarbon-impacted groundwater. Predominant processes comprising natural attenuation include biodegradation of hydrocarbons under the action of microorganisms indigenous to soil and groundwater; chemical transformation by subsurface chemical reactions; dispersion; sorption; and volatilization of volatile compounds from soil and groundwater. It should be noted that the decision to use natural attenuation can only be made after careful study of a site and local regulations.
Index Keywords: Adsorption; Biodegradation; Hydrocarbons; Microorganisms; Soil pollution; Volatile organic compounds; Bioremediation; Natural attenuation; Volatilization; Groundwater pollution

Authors: Robertson D., Smith C., Bolwell G.P.
Title: Inducible UDP-glucose dehydrogenase from French bean (Phaseolus vulgaris L.) locates to vascular tissue and has alcohol dehydrogenase activity
Affiliations: Department of Biochemistry, Royal Holloway and Bedford New College, University of London, Egham, Surrey TW20 0EX, United Kingdom; Unilever Research, Colworth House, Sharnbrook, Bedford MK44 1LQ, United Kingdom; Department of Biological Sciences, University of Durham, South Road, Durham DH1 3LE, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Robertson, D., Department of Biochemistry, Royal Holloway and Bedford New College, University of London, Egham, Surrey TW20 0EX, United Kingdom, Department of Biological Sciences, University of Durham, South Road, Durham DH1 3LE, United Kingdom; Smith, C., Unilever Research, Colworth House, Sharnbrook, Bedford MK44 1LQ, United Kingdom; Bolwell, G.P., Department of Biochemistry, Royal Holloway and Bedford New College, University of London, Egham, Surrey TW20 0EX, United Kingdom
Abstract: UDP-glucose dehydrogenase is responsible for channelling UDP-glucose into the pool of UDP-sugars utilized in the synthesis of wall matrix polysaccharides and glycoproteins. It has been purified to homogeneity from suspension-cultured cells of French bean by a combination of hydrophobic-interaction chromatography, gel filtration and dye-ligand chromatography. The enzyme had a subunit of M(r) 40000. K(m) values were measured for UDP-glucose as 5.5 ± 1.4 mM and for NAD+ as 20 ± 3 μM. It was subject to inhibition by UDP-xylose. UDP-glucose dehydrogenase activity co-purified with alcohol dehydrogenase activity from suspension-cultured cells, elicitor-treated cells and elongating hypocotyls, even when many additional chromatographic steps were employed subsequently. The protein from each source was resolved into virtually identical patterns of isoforms on two-dimensional isoelectric focusing/PAGE. However, a combination of peptide mapping and sequence analysis, gel analysis using activity staining and kinetic analysis suggests that both activities are a function of the same protein. An antibody was raised and used to immunolocalize UDP-glucose dehydrogenase to developing xylem and phloem of French bean hypocotyl. Together with data published previously, these results are consistent with an important role in the regulation of carbon flux into wall matrix polysaccharides.

Authors: Robertson J.
Title: Deposition mechanism of cubic boron nitride
Affiliations: Engineering Dept., Cambridge University, Cambridge CB2 1PZ, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Robertson, J., Engineering Dept., Cambridge University, Cambridge CB2 1PZ, United Kingdom
Abstract: The ion assisted deposition of cubic BN (c-BN) is argued to occur by subplantation, in which low energy ions are implanted below the surface to increase the local density. The situation differs from the case of tetrahedral amorphous carbon (ta-C), because the heteropolar bonding of BN stabilises its crystalline over the amorphous phase. This increases the atomic diffusion energy, which moves the optimum deposition conditions to higher ion energies and higher temperatures. A second difference is the use of ion-assisted deposition which is less efficient than direct subplantation as it creates both interstitials and vacancies rather than just the interstitials which directly increase density.
Author Keywords: Boron nitride; Deposition; Subplantation

Authors: Roche A.E.
Title: Validation of CH4 and N2O measurements by the cryogenic limb array etalon spectrometer instrument on the Upper Atmosphere Research Satellite
Affiliations: Lockheed Martin Palo Alto Res. Lab., Dept. 91-20, Bldg. 252, 3251 Hanover Street, Palo Alto, CA 94304, United States
Authors with affiliations: Roche, A.E., Lockheed Martin Palo Alto Res. Lab., Dept. 91-20, Bldg. 252, 3251 Hanover Street, Palo Alto, CA 94304, United States
Abstract: CH4 and N2O are useful as dynamical tracers of stratospheric air transport because of their long photochemical lifetimes over a wide range of altitudes. The cryogenic limb array etalon spectrometer (CLAES) instrument on the NASA UARS provided simultaneous global measurements of the altitude profiles of CH4 and N2O mixing ratios in the stratosphere between October 1, 1991, and May 5, 1993. Data between January 9, 1992, and May 5, 1993 (388 days), have been processed using version 7 data processing software, and this paper is concerned with the assessment of the quality of this data set. CLAES is a limb-viewing emission instrument, and approximately 1200 profiles were obtained each 24-hour period for each constituent over a nominal altitude range of 100 to 0.1 mbar (16 to 64 km). Each latitude was sampled 30 times per day between latitudes 34°S and 80°N, or 34°N and 80°S depending on the yaw direction of the UARS, and nearly all local times were sampled in about 36 days. This data set extends the altitude, latitude, and seasonal coverage of previous experiments, particularly in relation to measurements at high winter latitudes. To arrive at estimates of experiment error, we compared CLAES profiles for both gases with a wide variety of correlative data from ground-based, rocket, aircraft, balloon, and space-borne sensors, looked at the repeatability of multiple profiles in the same location, and carried out empirical estimates of experiment error based on knowledge of instrument characteristics. These analyses indicate an average single-profile CH4 systematic error of about 15% between 46 and 0.46 mbar, with CLAES biased high. The CH4 random error over this range is 0.08 to 0.05 parts per million, which translates to about 7% in the midstratosphere. For N2O the indicated systematic error is less than 15% at all altitudes between 68 and 2 mbar, with CLAES tending to be high below 6.8 mbar and low above. The N2O random error is 20 to 5 ppb between 46 and 2 mbar, which also translates to 7% in the low to midstratosphere. Both tracers have useful profile information to as low as 68 mbar, excluding the tropics, and as high as 0.2 mbar (CH4) and 1 mbar (N2O). The global fields show generally good spatial correlation and exhibit the major morphological and seasonal features seen in previous global field data. Several morphological features are pointed out for regions and conditions for which there have been essentially no previous data. These include the differential behavior of the tracer isopleths near and inside the Antarctic winter vortex, and local maxima in the tropics in 1992, probably associated with the Mount Pinatubo sulfate aerosol layer. Overall, the results of this validation exercise indicate that the version 7 CH4 and N2O data sets can be used with good confidence for quantitative and qualitative studies of stratospheric and lower-mesospheric atmospheric structure and dynamics. Copyright 1996 by the American Geophysical Union.
Index Keywords: CLAES; measurement validation; methane; nitrous oxide; spectrometer; UARS

Authors: Roche P.F., Lucas P.W., Hoare M.G., Aitken D.K., Smith C.H.
Title: An investigation of the 3-μm emission bands in planetary nebulae
Source title: Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society
Affiliations: Astrophys., Nucl./Astrophys. Lab., Physics Department, Oxford University, Keble Road, Oxford OX1 3RH, United Kingdom; Max Planck Institut fur Astronomie, Königstuhl 17, D-69117 Heidelberg, Germany; Physics Department, University of Hertfordshire, College Lane, Hatfield AL10 9AB, United Kingdom; Physics Department, University College, ADFA, Campbell, ACT 2600, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Roche, P.F., Astrophys., Nucl./Astrophys. Lab., Physics Department, Oxford University, Keble Road, Oxford OX1 3RH, United Kingdom; Lucas, P.W., Astrophys., Nucl./Astrophys. Lab., Physics Department, Oxford University, Keble Road, Oxford OX1 3RH, United Kingdom; Hoare, M.G., Max Planck Institut fur Astronomie, Königstuhl 17, D-69117 Heidelberg, Germany; Aitken, D.K., Physics Department, University of Hertfordshire, College Lane, Hatfield AL10 9AB, United Kingdom, Physics Department, University College, ADFA, Campbell, ACT 2600, Australia; Smith, C.H., Physics Department, University College, ADFA, Campbell, ACT 2600, Australia
Abstract: Spectra are presented of 21 planetary nebulae spanning the well-known, but still unidentified, narrow emission features at 3.2-3.6 μm. The equivalent width of the 3.29-μm emission band is strongly correlated with the gas-phase carbon-to-oxygen ratio, as expected for a band origin in carbon-rich grains or molecules. It displays an approximately linear dependence upon the C/O ratio, with a threshold near C/O ∼0.6. The emission band is present in 18 of the 21 nebulae, being absent in three of the six oxygen-rich objects and only weakly present in a fourth. The profile of the , 3.29-μm band is closely similar in all of the nebulae and distinct from the band profile seen in some stellar envelopes. Weaker emission features in the 3.4-3.5 μm region are detected in nine objects, and are prominent only in nitrogen-rich type I nebulae. The intensity of the 3.4-μm feature in these objects is correlated with that of the 3.29-μm band, while the ratio of the two bands is strongly correlated with the nitrogen abundance. Possible explanations for this behaviour are discussed.
Author Keywords: Dust, extinction; Infrared: ISM: Lines and bands; ISM: Abundances; Planetary nebulae: General

Authors: Roden E.E., Wetzel R.G.
Title: Organic carbon oxidation and suppression of methane production by microbial Fe(III) oxide reduction in vegetated and unvegetated freshwater wetland sediments
Affiliations: Department of Biological Sciences, University of Alabama, Tuscaloosa, AL 35487-0206, United States
Authors with affiliations: Roden, E.E., Department of Biological Sciences, University of Alabama, Tuscaloosa, AL 35487-0206, United States; Wetzel, R.G., Department of Biological Sciences, University of Alabama, Tuscaloosa, AL 35487-0206, United States
Abstract: High concentrations (20-75 moμl cm-3) of amorphous Fe(III) oxide were observed in unvegetated surface and Juncus effusus rhizosphere sediments of a freshwater wetland in the southeastern United States. Incubation experiments demonstrated that microbial Fe(III) oxide reduction suppressed sulfate reduction and methanogenesis in surface sediments and mediated ≥ 40% of depth-integrated (0-10 cm) unvegetated sediment carbon metabolism, compared to ≤ 10% for sulfate reduction. In situ CO2 and CH4 flux measurements verified that nonmethanogenic pathways accounted for ∼50% of unvegetated sediment carbon metabolism. Lower (∼10-fold) rates of dark/anaerobic CH4 flux from experimental vegetated cores relative to unvegetated controls suggested that methanogenesis was inhibited in the Juncus rhizosphere, in which active Fe(III) oxide reduction was indicated by the presence of low but readily detectable levels of dissolved and solid-phase Fe(II). Fe(III) oxide reduction accounted for 65% of total carbon metabolism in rhizosphere sediment incubations, compared to 22% for methanogenesis. In contrast, methanogenesis dominated carbon metabolism (72% of total) in experimental unvegetated sediment cores. The high Fe(III) oxide concentrations and reduction rates observed in unvegetated surface and Juncus rhizosphere sediments were perpetuated by rapid Fe(III) regeneration via oxidation of Fe(II) compounds coupled to O2 input from the overlying water and plant roots, respectively. The results indicate that Fe(III) oxide reduction could mediate a considerable amount of organic carbon oxidation and significantly suppress CH4 production in freshwater wetlands situated within globally extensive iron-rich tropical and subtropical soil regimes.

Authors: Roetzer H., Riesing J.
Title: Measurement of the contribution of a single plant to air pollution using the SF6-tracer technique
Source title: International Conference on Air Pollution - Proceedings
Affiliations: Seibersdorf Research Cent, Seibersdorf, Austria
Authors with affiliations: Roetzer, H., Seibersdorf Research Cent, Seibersdorf, Austria; Riesing, J., Seibersdorf Research Cent, Seibersdorf, Austria
Abstract: The SF6-tracer method is used to investigate the dispersion of single plumes and to assess their contributions to overall air pollution without interference by other emitters. The exhaust gases are labelled by adding continuously minute quantities of the tracer gas. The tracer gas SF6 is a chemically stable, non toxic gas that can be detected to a very high sensitivity. Measurements of the tracer concentration in air samples indicate the dilution of the plume at the sampling points. A description of the applied techniques and three case studies are presented in the paper.
Index Keywords: Air quality; Environmental impact; Flue gases; Land fill; Monitoring; Odors; Regional planning; Sampling; Steam power plants; Sulfur compounds; Air pollutants; Plumes; Sulfur hexafluoride technique; Thermal power plants; Tracer gas; Air pollution

Authors: Romero-López A.F., Gutirrez-Salinas R., García-Moreno R.
Title: Soot combustion during regeneration of filter ceramic traps for diesel engines
Affiliations: Instituto de IngenierÍa, UNAM
Authors with affiliations: Romero-López, A.F., Instituto de IngenierÍa, UNAM; Gutirrez-Salinas, R., Instituto de IngenierÍa, UNAM; García-Moreno, R., Instituto de IngenierÍa, UNAM
Abstract: A retro-fit system for buses and heavy duty trucks is presented, along with the mathematical modelling of soot (particulate matter or PM) combustion. In spite of the fact that the use of ceramic traps has lost popularity in the U.S. during the last few years, mainly due to the severe problems encountered during regeneration, a new approach to Diesel1 emissions control, is presented. Main objective is to attain the emissions levels set forth by the EPA for 1998, both on PM and NOx emissions. The very high levels of temperature required for thermal regeneration and elaborate controls, have almost eliminated the preference for ceramic filters. However, a new approach is presented by using catalyzed filters which considerably reduce the high temperature requirements. Along with the mathematical modelling a new hardware is presented, which is capable of performing filtering, regeneration, and operation with somewhat simpler and more economical controls. Improvements in the design of combustion chambers, higher injection pressures, better fuels and lubricants, etc., have made possible to re-think the concept of mechanical filtration of Diesel Particulate Matter (DPM). The development of the system has been partially sponsored by the Mexico City Goverment in an attempt to reduce the air pollution within the overloaded atmosphere of the large Mexico City Metropolitan Area (MCMA). Reported results are of the public domain. © Copyright 1996 Society of Automotive Engineers. Inc.
Index Keywords: Bandpass filters; Ceramic materials; Combustion chambers; Exhaust gases; Soot; Diesel particulate matters; Emissions control; Heavy duty trucks; High temperature; Injection pressures; Mexico City metropolitan areas; Particulate Matter; Thermal regeneration; Diesel engines

Authors: Romm J.J., Ervin C.A.
Title: How energy policies affect public health
Affiliations: Off. Ener. Efficiency Renewable E., Department of Energy, 1000 Independence Ave. SW, Washington, DC 20585, United States
Authors with affiliations: Romm, J.J., Off. Ener. Efficiency Renewable E., Department of Energy, 1000 Independence Ave. SW, Washington, DC 20585, United States; Ervin, C.A.
Abstract: THE CONNECTION BETWEEN energy policy and increased levels of respiratory and cardiopulmonary disease has become clearer in the past few years. People living in cities with high levels of pollution have a higher risk of mortality than those living in less polluted cities. The pollutants most directly linked to increased morbidity and mortality include ozone, particulates, carbon monoxide, sulfur dioxide, volatile organic compounds, and oxides of nitrogen. Energy-related emissions generate the vast majority of these polluting chemicals. Technologies to prevent pollution in the transportation, manufacturing, building, and utility sectors can significantly reduce these emissions while reducing the energy bills of consumers and businesses. In short, clean energy technologies represent a very cost-effective investment in public health. Some 72% of the Federal government's investment in the research, development, and demonstration of pollution prevention technologies is made by the Department of Energy, with the largest share provided by the Office of Energy Efficiency and Renewable Energy. This article will examine the connections between air pollution and health problems and will discuss what the Department of Energy is doing to prevent air pollution now and in the future.

Authors: Rosen M.A., Sy E., Gharghouri P.
Title: Impact of natural gas substitution and utility-based cogeneration for industrial process heating
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Heat Transfer Division, (Publication) HTD
Affiliations: Department of Mechanical Engineering, Ryerson Polytechnic University, Toronto, Ont. M5B 2K3, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Rosen, M.A., Department of Mechanical Engineering, Ryerson Polytechnic University, Toronto, Ont. M5B 2K3, Canada; Sy, E., Department of Mechanical Engineering, Ryerson Polytechnic University, Toronto, Ont. M5B 2K3, Canada; Gharghouri, P., Department of Mechanical Engineering, Ryerson Polytechnic University, Toronto, Ont. M5B 2K3, Canada
Abstract: Significant benefits in the form of reduced energy use related emissions are shown to be possible in the province of Ontario, Canada by (i) substituting natural gas heating for electric heating, and (ii) implementing utility-based cogeneration, using the facilities of the main provincial electrical utility, Ontario Hydro, to satisfy some of the needs for industrial process heating in the province. Examinations of a wide range of practical substitution levels shows the greatest benefits from substitution to be realized in the utility sector, where marked reductions occur in coal and uranium use. Two cogeneration scenarios are assessed, which assume implementation of utility-based cogeneration to satisfy minor or major portions of the heat demands of the industrial sector, and which show that cogeneration can provide significant technical, economic and environmental benefits to the province and its electrical utility. The results are most likely to be useful to the developers and designers of energy systems, and to decision makers on energy planning and policy.
Index Keywords: Coal; Cogeneration plants; Electric heating; Electric utilities; Energy efficiency; Energy policy; Gas heating; Natural gas; Uranium; Energy planning; Energy system; Natural gas heating; Utility based cogeneration; Industrial heating

Authors: Rosenzweig C., Phillips J., Goldberg R., Carroll J., Hodges T.
Title: Potential impacts of climate change on citrus and potato production in the US
Affiliations: Center for Climate Systems Research, Columbia University, Goddard Institute for Space Studies, New York, NY 10025, United States; Dept. of Land, Air/Water Resources, University of California at Davis, Davis, CA 95616, United States; USDA-ARS, Prosser, WA 99350, United States
Authors with affiliations: Rosenzweig, C., Center for Climate Systems Research, Columbia University, Goddard Institute for Space Studies, New York, NY 10025, United States; Phillips, J., Center for Climate Systems Research, Columbia University, Goddard Institute for Space Studies, New York, NY 10025, United States; Goldberg, R., Center for Climate Systems Research, Columbia University, Goddard Institute for Space Studies, New York, NY 10025, United States; Carroll, J., Dept. of Land, Air/Water Resources, University of California at Davis, Davis, CA 95616, United States; Hodges, T., USDA-ARS, Prosser, WA 99350, United States
Abstract: Potential impacts of global climate change on fruit and vegetable yield in the US were investigated through simulations of citrus and potato. Simulated treatments included combinations of three increased temperature regimes (+1.5, +2.5 and +5.0°C), and estimates of the impact of three levels of atmospheric carbon dioxide (440, 530, and 600 ppm) in addition to control runs representing current climatic conditions. Adaptive planting dates of - 28, -14, +14 and +28 days were included in the potato simulations for current and increased temperature regimes. Twenty-two sites were simulated for citrus yields and 12 sites for potato, using climate records from 1951 to 1980. Response surfaces were developed for all combinations of increased temperature and CO2. Results of citrus simulations without CO2-induced yield improvement indicate that production may shift slightly northward in the southern states, but yields may decline in southern Florida and Texas due to excessive heat during the winter. CO2 effects tended to counteract the decline in simulated citrus yields. Fall potato production under current management practices appears vulnerable to an increase in temperature in the northern states; increased CO2 and changes in planting date were estimated to have minimal compensating impacts on simulated potato yields.
Index Keywords: carbon dioxide; citrus; climate change; climatic change; fruit yield; potato; temperature; vegetable yield; yield; yield impact; USA, Florida; USA, Texas; Citrus; Magnoliophyta; Rutaceae; Solanaceae; Solanum tuberosum; Tuberosum

Abstract: High-resolution Fourier transform spectra of the laser-induced fluorescence of copper dichloride produced in a free-jet expansion are presented. The supersonic molecular beam produces rotational cooling and a nearly collision-free environment. Dispersed fluorescence spectra are found to be free of the continuum which restricted the data obtainable with a classical source (hot cell). The reduction in thermal emission allows the fluorescence to be recorded from the laser line (585 nm) out to 1.3 μm, revealing many new vibrational levels of CuCl2 in its ground electronic state, X̃ 2Πg(3/2). © 1996 Academic Press, Inc.

Authors: Rothstein Richard A., Epstein Harold E., Kubali Volkan, Jacobs Michael B., Wallace Marc C.
Title: Issues associated with siting wind turbine generators at Industrial Coastal sites in Massachusetts to satisfy ozone nonattainment mandates
Source title: Proceedings of the Air & Waste Management Association's Annual Meeting & Exhibition
Authors with affiliations: Rothstein, Richard A.; Epstein, Harold E.; Kubali, Volkan; Jacobs, Michael B.; Wallace, Marc C.
Abstract: The mid-Atlantic and northeastern states forming the Ozone Transport Region (OTR), per the 1990 Clean Air Act Amendments (CAA), continue to develop regional NOx control strategies. The goal is to bring each state, and ultimately the entire region, into attainment for ozone. This can be accomplished, in part, through effective control of NOx emissions from major stationary combustion sources. The lack of 'air borders' when it comes to interstate transport of ozone and precursor compound emissions (NOx and VOC), presents significant regulatory challenges. Pressure exists for states to further tighten allowable NOx RACT emission limits. However, preliminary photochemical modeling suggests that only modest NOx controls may be needed, and Massachusetts does not want to economically constrain itself through 'over-regulation.' Use of innovative 'zero emissions' technologies such as wind turbine generators is a potentially viable alternative to conventional power sources, and appears premising in light of recent technological advances. Such strategies may be sufficient to help large combustion sources obtain the necessary modest reductions of NOx emissions during high ozone episodes. Cost-effective reduction of peak energy demand can aid in achieving regional compliance for ozone. The Commonwealth of Massachusetts is conducting a study of technical and regulatory feasibility of siting wind turbine generators at the 780 MGD Deer Island wastewater treatment plant in Boston. This plant, located near Logan International Airport, is undergoing extensive reconstruction that presents sane unique siting challenges. Collected an-site meteorological data will be used to define daily and seasonal patterns of wind availability, and can be later compared with utility system demand. Future study goals include ascertaining the magnitude of reduced NOx emission levels if eventually deploying coastal-sited wind farms. Potential utility system benefits from urban siting of zero emission power systems based on recent theoretical investigations are also discussed.
Index Keywords: Cost effectiveness; Gas emissions; Laws and legislation; Mathematical models; Nitrogen oxides; Ozone; Sewage treatment plants; Strategic planning; Turbogenerators; Urban planning; Volatile organic compounds; Wastewater treatment; Industrial coastal sites; Massachusetts; Ozone transport region; Siting wind turbine generators; Air pollution control

Authors: Ruddy Edward N.
Title: Particulate control technologies for reduction of hazardous air pollutant emissions
Source title: Proceedings of the Air & Waste Management Association's Annual Meeting & Exhibition
Authors with affiliations: Ruddy, Edward N.
Abstract: Hazardous Air Pollutant (HAP) emissions controls are being utilized in greater numbers that ever before. The demand for more efficient and cost effective controls has further the development of new technologies and driven the improvement of existing technologies to new heights. In previous years particulate controls were typically applied to drying and grinding processes, particulate application, dirty combustion processes (i.e. coal combustion) coke production, metals processing, etc. However, over the last few years, particularly since the advent of the Clean Air Act Amendments of 1990, the range of processes requiring effective particulate controls has expanded to include plating shops, municipal waste combustion, and coating applications. In some cases these requirements have been new to the industry, in others the control requirements have been increased significantly in response to health concerns and regulatory development. The purpose of this paper is to describe some of the changes that have occurred in particulate emission control requirements in the last 5-10 years, and the improvements and innovations that have occurred in particulate control technology as a result. Included with this analysis will be a synopsis of the current regulatory trends in requiring particulate controls.
Index Keywords: Cost effectiveness; Hazardous materials; Laws and legislation; Particulate emissions; Technology transfer; Hazardous air pollutant emissions; Particulate control technologies; Air pollution control

Authors: Rudolf B., Hauschild H., Rüth W., Schneider U.
Title: Comparison of raingauge analyses, satellite-based precipitation estimates and forecast model results
Affiliations: Global Precipitation Climatol. Ctr., Deutscher Wetterdienst, Postfach 10 04 65, D-63004 Offenbach, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Rudolf, B., Global Precipitation Climatol. Ctr., Deutscher Wetterdienst, Postfach 10 04 65, D-63004 Offenbach, Germany; Hauschild, H., Global Precipitation Climatol. Ctr., Deutscher Wetterdienst, Postfach 10 04 65, D-63004 Offenbach, Germany; Rüth, W., Global Precipitation Climatol. Ctr., Deutscher Wetterdienst, Postfach 10 04 65, D-63004 Offenbach, Germany; Schneider, U., Global Precipitation Climatol. Ctr., Deutscher Wetterdienst, Postfach 10 04 65, D-63004 Offenbach, Germany
Abstract: Observed precipitation data are required for the verification of weather prediction and climate models. Information on precipitation is available from different observation techniques, on global scale from networks of raingauge stations and from satellite remotely sensed data. Both data sources include certain deficiencies. Raingauge measurements are nearly not available over the oceans. They are point measurements, which are locally influenced, and are contaminated by systematic measuring errors. However, these conventional measurements give the best estimate of the true precipitation amount, if the network density is sufficient. Several climatologies based on conventional observations have been published. Satellite data cover land and oceans and provide area-means, but the precipitation estimates are based on indirect approachs and need to be calibrated and validated. This paper will give some intercomparisons, which have been carried out in the framework of the World Climate Research Programme's Global Precipitation Climatology Project.
Index Keywords: atmospheric precipitations; rain gauges; raingauge data; satellite precipitation data; satellite sensing

Authors: Russak V.
Title: Atmospheric aerosol variability in Estonia calculated from solar radiation measurements
Source title: Tellus, Series A: Dynamic Meteorology and Oceanography
Affiliations: Inst. Astrophys. and Atmosph. Phys., Estonian Acad. Sciences, EE 2444 Tõravere, Estonia
Authors with affiliations: Russak, V., Inst. Astrophys. and Atmosph. Phys., Estonian Acad. Sciences, EE 2444 Tõravere, Estonia
Abstract: Direct solar radiation data obtained during 1955-1994 at the Tõravere Actinometric Station (Estonia) have been used to study the long-term variations of the atmospheric aerosol. In a linear approximation, the optical thickness of atmospheric aerosol averaged over months from April to August has increased by 73% at Tõravere during the last 40 years. The aerosol loading of the atmosphere depends on wind direction, the southern and southeastern winds being the main carriers of aerosol. During the last decade, the increase in the optical thickness of aerosol in the case of W-, NW- and N-winds has slowed down. This is most likely caused by a reduction in the SO2 emission in Western and Central Europe as well as in Finland. In April, the advection of aerosol is greatest from the NE-direction. We suppose that this effect points to the possibility of aerosol transfer to Estonia through the Arctic regions.
Index Keywords: aerosol; optical thickness; solar radiation; Estonia, Tartu-Toravere Actinometric Station

Authors: Rutherford M.C., O'Callaghan M., Powrie L.W., Hurford J.L., Schulze R.E.
Title: Predicting survival in new environments through analytical GIS application
Affiliations: National Botanical Institute, P/Bag X7, Claremont 7735, South Africa; University of Natal, P/Box 375, Pietermaritzburg 3201, South Africa
Authors with affiliations: Rutherford, M.C., National Botanical Institute, P/Bag X7, Claremont 7735, South Africa; O'Callaghan, M., National Botanical Institute, P/Bag X7, Claremont 7735, South Africa; Powrie, L.W., National Botanical Institute, P/Bag X7, Claremont 7735, South Africa; Hurford, J.L., National Botanical Institute, P/Bag X7, Claremont 7735, South Africa; Schulze, R.E., University of Natal, P/Box 375, Pietermaritzburg 3201, South Africa
Abstract: Predicted climate change is expected to impact many biological populations independently of their current equilibrium-level community affiliations. A model is presented that uses environmental response surface, dispersal potential, plant longevity, and climate change vectors to predict the survival of various plant species populations with differing terrain types. These types include actual Geographical Information System (GIS) cases from southern Africa with multiple levels of landscape permeability and discontinuity. Examples include terrain slope configurations that satisfy survival requirements of different plant populations with expected climate change. Copyright © 1996 Elsevier Science Ltd.

Authors: Ryan W.B.F., Flood R.D.
Title: Side-looking sonar backscatter response at dual frequencies
Affiliations: Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory, Columbia University, Palisades, NY, United States; Marine Sciences Research Center, State University of New York, Stony Brook, NY, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ryan, W.B.F., Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory, Columbia University, Palisades, NY, United States; Flood, R.D., Marine Sciences Research Center, State University of New York, Stony Brook, NY, United States
Abstract: Dual-frequency side-looking sonars have the potential to be used as remote sensing tools to characterize subaqueous terrains. In one case study of the carbonate-ooze-coated Blake Plateau offshore of Georgia, U.S.A., the difference in acoustic attenuation for 50 and 20 mm wavelengths (30 and 72 kHz frequency) permits the discrimination of sub-bottom scatterers from seabed surface textural features to reveal patchy regions where a buried hard ground had been pock-marked by karst-like depressions. In a second study of the Upper Hudson River in New York, U.S.A., related to environmental contaminates, the backscatter response at 15 and 3 mm acoustic wavelengths (100 and 500 kHz frequency) serves as a useful proxy for sediment grain size with coarser detritus distinguished from finer sediments. Sand and gravel regions inferred from the backscatter were confirmed by ground truth sampling. © 1996 Kluwer Academic Publishers.
Author Keywords: Attenuation; Backscatter; Blake Plateau; Hard ground; Hudson River; Reverberation; Side-looking sonar; Terrain classification
