Authors: Schueler R.Alan
Title: Air pollution distance learning network: an integrated approach to electronic distance education and training
Source title: Proceedings of the Air & Waste Management Association's Annual Meeting & Exhibition
Authors with affiliations: Schueler, R.Alan
Abstract: The Air Pollution Distance Learning Network (APDLN) emerged in 1994 as the primary national means of providing training to governmental air pollution staff throughout the United States. The APDLN is a digital video system broadcasting via satellite to downlinks at state and local environmental agencies as well as a few universities. Funding is provided by the U.S. EPA through a cooperative agreement with North Carolina State University. The APDLN began as a means of delivering traditional Air Pollution Training Institute short courses simultaneously to large numbers of students. Its programming is now evolving toward an array of technical training workshops, some structured courses, and regulatory update workshops and seminars. In addition, electronic delivery of training materials and prerequisite courses via the Internet and EPA electronic bulletin boards is being integrated with the satellite broadcasts, and a means for asynchronous post-broadcast communication between students and presenters is being implemented. The paper will provide an assessment of this combination of distance education techniques, with emphasis on resource requirements, instructional effectiveness, cost effectiveness, and impact on EPA's national air training effort. In addition, it will provide an overview of current planning for wider implementation of distance learning techniques.
Index Keywords: Computer networks; Digital communication systems; Education; Personnel training; Satellite relay systems; Technical presentations; Television broadcasting; Air pollution distance learning network; Digital video system broadcasting; Electronic bulletin boards; Internet; Air pollution

Authors: Schuerer C., Rathjen D.
Title: Diamond-like carbon: production, properties and applications
Affiliations: Inst fuer Physikalische und, Mechanische Technologien Chemnitz, Lassallestr, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Schuerer, C., Inst fuer Physikalische und, Mechanische Technologien Chemnitz, Lassallestr, Germany; Rathjen, D., Inst fuer Physikalische und, Mechanische Technologien Chemnitz, Lassallestr, Germany
Abstract: The scientific and technical interest in wear- and friction reducing carbon layers with diamond-like properties (DLC) for surface refinement has continuously increased in recent years. In the literature this material is also called 'a-C:H' but 'i-carbon' sometimes. This publication refers to the deposition of DLC coatings in an unsustained hydrocarbon d.c.-glowdischarge both for industrial application tests and for measuring the film properties. Besides a description of the deposition method a review of some typical mechanical layer properties is given. This paper briefly describes the present state of the DLC-technique developed by GFE e.V. It concludes with a brief discussion of the practical advantages of the DLC-process used industrially in several fields and of remaining problems to be studied in further experiments.
Index Keywords: Carbon; Coatings; Deposition; Friction; Glow discharges; Industrial applications; Materials testing; Production; Wear of materials; Diamond like carbon; Hydrocarbon DC glowdischarge; Surface refinement; Diamond films

Authors: Schulte N., Fröhlich R., Hecht J., Würthwein E.-U.
Title: Unsaturated hetero chains, V: Synthesis, structure, and reactivity of alkoxy-substituted 2,4-diazapentadienylium-, 2,4,6-triazaheptatrienylium-, and 2,4,6,8-tetraazanonatetraenylium salts
Affiliations: Organisch-Chemisches Institut, Westfälische Wilhelms-Universität Münster, Corrensstraße 40, D-48149 Münster, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Schulte, N., Organisch-Chemisches Institut, Westfälische Wilhelms-Universität Münster, Corrensstraße 40, D-48149 Münster, Germany; Fröhlich, R., Organisch-Chemisches Institut, Westfälische Wilhelms-Universität Münster, Corrensstraße 40, D-48149 Münster, Germany; Hecht, J., Organisch-Chemisches Institut, Westfälische Wilhelms-Universität Münster, Corrensstraße 40, D-48149 Münster, Germany; Würthwein, E.-U., Organisch-Chemisches Institut, Westfälische Wilhelms-Universität Münster, Corrensstraße 40, D-48149 Münster, Germany
Abstract: The 1-mono- and 1,ω-dialkoxy-substituted 2,4-diazapentadienylium, 2,4,6-triazaheptatrienylium, and 2,4,6,8-tetraazanonatetraenylium salts 3, 5, and 10 were synthesized by oxonium salt alkylation of the corresponding 1-oxa-3,5-diazahexatrienes 1, of the 1-oxa-3,5,7-triazaoctatetraenes 4, and of the 1-oxa-3,5,7,9-tetraazadecapentaenes 7. The salts 3 and 10 are sufficiently stable to facilitate their isolation whereas salt 5 decomposes readily. For the synthesis of the alkoxysubstituted 1-oxa-3,5,7,9-tetraazadecapentaenes 7 a new general pathway was developed, which involves the condensation of the salts 3 with the N-acylamidines 6. The structural properties in the crystalline state were determined for the salts 3d and 10a as well as for the neutral compound 7a by X-ray crystallography. All three compounds are characterized by non-planar helical chains, much in contrast to their planar all-carbon analogous polyenes and polymethinium salts. From the UV/Vis spectra we deduce that these compounds prefer non-planar structures also in solution. All stable compounds were completely characterized by analytical and spectroscopic methods. © VCH Verlagsgesellschaft mbH, 1996.

Authors: Schwartz B., Vogel K.W., Drueckhammer D.G.
Title: Coenzyme A hemithioacetals as easily prepared inhibitors of CoA ester-utilizing enzymes
Affiliations: Department of Chemistry, Stanford University, Stanford, CA 94305, United States
Authors with affiliations: Schwartz, B., Department of Chemistry, Stanford University, Stanford, CA 94305, United States; Vogel, K.W., Department of Chemistry, Stanford University, Stanford, CA 94305, United States; Drueckhammer, D.G., Department of Chemistry, Stanford University, Stanford, CA 94305, United States
Abstract: Hemithioacetals are formed by reactions of coenzyme A (CoA) with aldehydes in aqueous solution. Equilibria for hemithioacetal formation with four commercially available aldehydes and rate constants for hemithioacetal dissociation have been studied. The hemithioacetals are viewed as acyl-CoA analogs having a tetrahedral center in place of the planar trigonal thioester carbonyl carbon. These compounds may serve as mimics of the tetrahedral intermediate or transition state in the reactions of acyl-CoA dependent acyltransferase enzymes. The hemithioacetal generated by reaction of CoA with formaldehyde is a poor inhibitor of chloramphenicol acetyltransferase, with a K(i) more than 6-fold higher than the K(m) for the substrate acetyl-CoA. The hemithioacetals formed by reaction of CoA with acetaldehyde and trifluroacetaldehyde are substantially better inhibitors, with K(i) values approximately 2.4-fold and 10-fold lower than the K(m) values for acetyl-CoA, respectively. The hemithioacetal formed by reaction of CoA with succinic semialdehyde inhibits succinic thiokinase, with a K(i) 4-fold lower than the K(m) for the substrate succinyl-CoA. The CoA hemithioacetals provide a novel readily accessible new class of acyl-CoA analogs for use in mechanistic and structural studies of CoA ester-utilizing enzymes.
Index Keywords: acetyl coenzyme a; acyltransferase; chloramphenicol acetyltransferase; citrate synthase; coenzyme a derivative; succinyl coenzyme a synthetase; unclassified drug; article; drug structure; drug synthesis; enzyme inhibition; nuclear magnetic resonance

Authors: Scott A.C., Galtier J.
Title: A review of the problems in the stratigraphical, palaeoecological and palaeobiogeographical interpretation of Lower Carboniferous (Dinantian) floras from Western Europe
Affiliations: Geology Department, Royal Holloway University of London, Egham, Surrey, TW20 OEX, United Kingdom; Laboratoire de Paléobotanique, URA 327 CNRS, Université des Sciences et Techniques du Languedoc, Place E. Bataillon, 34060 Montpellier, France
Authors with affiliations: Scott, A.C., Geology Department, Royal Holloway University of London, Egham, Surrey, TW20 OEX, United Kingdom; Galtier, J., Laboratoire de Paléobotanique, URA 327 CNRS, Université des Sciences et Techniques du Languedoc, Place E. Bataillon, 34060 Montpellier, France
Abstract: Investigations of Lower Carboniferous floras from Western Europe by the authors have indicated dramatic evolutionary changes from the early Tournaisian to the late Viséan. In addition, distinctive facies controls can be identified. Utilizing data from both anatomically preserved plants and compressions, broad controls upon the distribution of taxa can be identified. The composition of a flora will reflect not only palaeobiogeography but also stratigraphic age, ecology, facies distribution, preservation, intensity of collection and study. Most recent palaeogeographical analyses have relied on published data which rarely documents all of these facets. In addition, different authors world wide have quite different concepts of the taxa concerned so that a statistical analysis using published lists may have little value. In this paper we examine the spacial and temporal distribution of Lower Carboniferous plants from Western Europe. In particular, adjacent localities of the same age may have distinctly different floras reflecting ecological and taphonomic controls. When viewed outside their geological context they could easily be considered as floras of different ages or from different biological provinces. We present a revised stratigraphic distribution of key genera of anatomically preserved plants in Western Europe. We believe that, particularly in the Lower Carboniferous where rapid evolution of several plant groups can be demonstrated, accurate dating of the floras is an essential prerequisite to all other studies. The identification of three major assemblages from the early/mid Tournaisian, late Tournaisian/early Viséan and late Viséan is confirmed with new data. © 1996 Elsevier Science B.V. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: biostratigraphy; Carboniferous; Dinantian; floral assemblage; palaeobiogeography; palaeoecology; Europe, (West)

Authors: Selden P.A., Shear W.A.
Title: The first Mesozoic solifugae (arachnida), from the Cretaceous of Brazil, and a redescription of the Palaeozoic solifuge
Affiliations: Department of Earth Sciences, University of Manchester, Manchester M13 9PL, United Kingdom; Department of Biology, Hampden-Sydney College, Hampden-Sydney, VA 23943, United States
Authors with affiliations: Selden, P.A., Department of Earth Sciences, University of Manchester, Manchester M13 9PL, United Kingdom; Shear, W.A., Department of Biology, Hampden-Sydney College, Hampden-Sydney, VA 23943, United States
Abstract: The first Mesozoic solifuge, from the Early Cretaceous (Aptian) Crato Formation of Ceará province, Brazil, is described and named as Cratosolpuga wunderlichi Seiden, gen. et sp. nov. and placed in the extant family Ceromidae. There are two previously described fossil solifuges: from Palaeogene Dominican amber and the Carboniferous (Westphalian D) Francis Creek Shale of Mazon Creek, Illinois. The latter specimen (Protosolpuga carbonaria), redescribed herein, is poorly preserved but provides evidence for the presence of the order in the Carboniferous.

Authors: Sengupta S., Patil R.S., Venkatachalam P.
Title: Assessment of population exposure and risk zones due to air pollution using the geographical information system
Affiliations: Indian Institute of Technology, Bombay, 400 076, India
Authors with affiliations: Sengupta, S., Indian Institute of Technology, Bombay, 400 076, India; Patil, R.S., Indian Institute of Technology, Bombay, 400 076, India; Venkatachalam, P., Indian Institute of Technology, Bombay, 400 076, India
Abstract: Unplanned urbanization and industrialization are causing deterioration of the environment and quality of life in the developing countries. It is essential to assess the spatial distribution of air quality and its impact on human beings in the urban region. A large data base is required to estimate the human exposure to air pollution. The Geographical Information System (GIS), which is especially suited for handling data with large spatially distributed features, is a valuable tool for estimation of population exposure. In this study an indigenously, developed GIS package GRAM has been used to assess the exposure and health risk of the population of the Greater Bombay region from atmospheric pollutants. The population and the built-up area are growing rapidly, and the concentration of air pollutants is large in the eastern and central parts of the city. Interpolated maps of three pollutants have been created using GIS to calculate the Air Quality Index (AQI). Maps of population density and population growth give an idea of the pressure of population on the land. The final map generated by overlaying the AQI map and population pressure map helps to demarcate five pollutant risk zones in Greater Bombay. This map is useful for developing various air pollution management strategies. Thus GIS can be used as an efficient tool for environment planning. © 1997 Elsevier Science Ltd.
Index Keywords: Population air pollution exposure estimation; Software package GRAM; Air pollution; Air quality; Computer software; Database systems; Developing countries; Geographic information systems; Maps; Zoning; Urban planning; air pollution; air quality index; anthropogenic impact; atmospheric pollutant; developing country; GIS; GRAM; health risk; management strategy; risk assessment; India, Maharashtra, Bombay

Authors: Seo D.-J., Smith J.A.
Title: Characterization of the climatological variability of mean areal rainfall through fractional coverage
Affiliations: Hydrologic Research Laboratory, National Weather Service, Silver Spring, MD, United States; Dept. Civ. Eng. and Operations Res., Princeton University, Princeton, NJ, United States; Hydrologic Research Laboratory, W/073, National Weather Service, 1325 East-West Highway, Silver Spring, MD 20910, United States; Dept. Civ. Eng. and Operations Res., Princeton University, Princeton, NJ 08544, United States
Authors with affiliations: Seo, D.-J., Hydrologic Research Laboratory, National Weather Service, Silver Spring, MD, United States, Hydrologic Research Laboratory, W/073, National Weather Service, 1325 East-West Highway, Silver Spring, MD 20910, United States; Smith, J.A., Dept. Civ. Eng. and Operations Res., Princeton University, Princeton, NJ, United States, Dept. Civ. Eng. and Operations Res., Princeton University, Princeton, NJ 08544, United States
Abstract: The role of fractional coverage in climatological variability of mean areal rainfall is investigated. Under second-order homogeneity assumptions, climatological variability of mean areal rainfall, as measured by its coefficient of variation, is shown to be a function of mean fractional coverage, conditional coefficient of variation of point rainfall and two correlation scales associated with inner variability and intermittency of point rainfall. To verify the analytical results, empirical analyses are performed using hourly rainfall data from nine Weather Surveillance Radar- 1988 Doppler (WSR-88D) radars in the southern plains, United States. The results indicate that given the local rainfall climatology there exists a catchment scale at which the climatological variability of mean areal rainfall is at its maximum. Existence of such a scale has been hypothesized and demonstrated via an analytical treatment of an idealized situation by Eagleson and Wang [1985], but only in climatological variability of fractional coverage (i.e., variability due only to intermittency). Sensitivity analyses for the correlation-scale parameters indicate that intermittency plays as important a role as inner variability in shaping the catchment scale-climatological variability relationship of mean areal rainfall. Decomposition of total variability indicates that over the range of catchment scales that fall within a single WSR-88D radar umbrella (effective radius of 230 km) the integrated contribution from intermittency is almost as large as that from inner variability.
Index Keywords: rain; catchment; decomposition; radius; sensitivity analysis; telecommunication; United States; weather; areal rainfall; hydrological model; rainfall

Authors: Shackley S., Wynne B.
Title: Representing uncertainty in global climate change science and policy: Boundary-ordering devices and authority
Affiliations: Ctr. the Stud. of Environ. Change, Lancaster University, Lancaster LA1 4YN, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Shackley, S., Ctr. the Stud. of Environ. Change, Lancaster University, Lancaster LA1 4YN, United Kingdom; Wynne, B.
Abstract: This article argues that, in public and policy contexts, the ways in which many scientists talk about uncertainty in simulations of future climate change not only facilitates communications and cooperation between scientific and policy communities but also affects the perceived authority of science. Uncertainty tends to challenge the authority of climate science, especially if it is used for policy making, but the relationship between authority and uncertainty is not simply an inverse one. In policy contexts, many scientists are compelled to talk about uncertainty but do not wish to imply that uncertainty is a serious challenge to the authority of scientific knowledge or to its substantial use in policy making. "Boundary-ordering devices," the contextual discursive attempts to reconcile uncertainty and authority in science, depend critically for their success on their "dual" interpretation: at a general level across a boundary and differently on either side of it. The authors empirically identify a range of such boundary-ordering devices in the climate field.

Authors: Shan W., Schmidt T., Yang X.H., Song J.J., Goldenberg B.
Title: Optical properties of wurtzite GaN grown by low-pressure metalorganic chemical-vapor deposition
Affiliations: Center for Laser Research, Department of Physics, Oklahoma State University, Stillwater, OK 74078, United States; Honeywell Technology Center, Plymouth, MN 55420, United States
Authors with affiliations: Shan, W., Center for Laser Research, Department of Physics, Oklahoma State University, Stillwater, OK 74078, United States; Schmidt, T., Center for Laser Research, Department of Physics, Oklahoma State University, Stillwater, OK 74078, United States; Yang, X.H., Center for Laser Research, Department of Physics, Oklahoma State University, Stillwater, OK 74078, United States; Song, J.J., Center for Laser Research, Department of Physics, Oklahoma State University, Stillwater, OK 74078, United States; Goldenberg, B., Honeywell Technology Center, Plymouth, MN 55420, United States
Abstract: We present the results of optical studies on the properties of GaN grown by low-pressure metalorganic chemical-vapor deposition, with emphasis on the issues vital to device applications such as stimulated emission and laser action as well as carrier relaxation dynamics. By optical pumping, stimulated emission and lasing were investigated over a wide temperature range up to 420 K. Using a picosecond streak camera, the free and bound exciton emission decay times were examined. In addition, the effects of temperature and pressure on the optical interband transitions and the transitions associated with impurity/defect states were studied using a variety of spectroscopic methods, including photoluminescence and photoreflectance. The fundamental band gap of GaN was mapped out as a function of temperature using the empirical Varshni relation. The pressure coefficient of the gap was determined using diamond-anvil pressure-cell technique. The hydrostatic deformation potential for the direct Γ band gap was also derived from the experimental results. © 1996 American Institute of Physics.
Index Keywords: Calculations; Electron transitions; Emission spectroscopy; Energy gap; Excitons; Metallorganic chemical vapor deposition; Optical properties; Photoluminescence; Pressure effects; Relaxation processes; Streak cameras; Thermal effects; Carrier capture process; Diamond anvil cell; Gallium nitride; Hydrostatic deformation potential; Photoreflectance spectroscopy; Radiative decay; Stimulated emission; Stimulated lasing; Varshni relation; Semiconducting gallium compounds

Authors: Shang-Ping Xie
Title: Effects of seasonal solar forcing on latitudinal asymmetry of the ITCZ
Authors with affiliations: Shang-Ping Xie
Abstract: A coupled ocean-atmosphere model is used to investigate the effects of seasonal variation in solar radiation on the configuration of the intertropical convergence zone. The model maintains a Northern Hemispheric ITCZ under annual mean insolation, with convection being suppressed in the Southern Hemisphere. In the presence of seasonal variations, a Southern Hemispheric ITCZ develops in boreal winter and spring in response to the seasonal rise in local solar radiation. As a result, the equatorial asymmetry of the annual-mean model climatology is reduced. The latitudinal asymmetry of the model climate is thus determined by a balance between symmetry-breaking land forcing and the symmetry-restoring seasonal solar forcing.
Index Keywords: atmosphere/ocean coupling; ITCZ; solar radiation

Authors: Shapiro M.
Title: Theory of two-photon adiabatic passage: Absorption to and emission from N states
Source title: Physical Review A - Atomic, Molecular, and Optical Physics
Affiliations: Department of Chemical Physics, The Weizmann Institute of Science, Rehovot, 76100, Israel
Authors with affiliations: Shapiro, M., Department of Chemical Physics, The Weizmann Institute of Science, Rehovot, 76100, Israel
Abstract: An analytic theory of resonantly enhanced two-photon excitation of N states with laser light of an arbitrary field is developed. Closed-form expressions for the time evolution of the system are derived. The formulation is used to explore adiabatic passage to a level embedded amongst N other levels. ‘‘Counterintuitive’’ pulse sequence is shown to lead to complete population transfer under adiabatic conditions. The reverse case of stimulated emission from N initial states is also studied. Complete population transfer to the ground state from an initial state satisfying the two-photon resonance condition is shown to be possible. © 1996 The American Physical Society.

Authors: Sharma Kavi, Mitchell R.T.
Title: Computerized data management in Title V recordkeeping and reporting
Source title: Proceedings of the Air & Waste Management Association's Annual Meeting & Exhibition
Authors with affiliations: Sharma, Kavi; Mitchell, R.T.
Abstract: The implementation of the Clean Air Act Amendments (CAAA) of 1990 along with other data intensive environmental regulations such as Emergency Planning and Community Right to know Act (EPCRA) has significantly increased the data management burden on the industry. The CAAA Title V program alone requires major sources to track at least six criteria pollutants as well as the 189 Hazardous Air Pollutants and other regulated chemicals. This paper discusses the use of a computerized data management system for decreasing the burden of recordkeeping and reporting requirements. It focuses on the requirements of a good data management system with emphasis on three primary aspects: data entry, analysis and reporting. The data entry interface should be as user friendly as possible, thereby, taking away the time consuming exercise of data entry from technical staff. There are certain key data elements which are required as system inputs for a comprehensive Title V air emissions analysis: MSDS, purchase/usage, emission factors, process and operational data. The analytical capability of a system is dependent on its design. The study examines potential software platforms for designing such a system including spreadsheets, flat file databases and relational databases. Regardless of the software selection there are certain features which make a system efficient and time-saving. The utility of a good system lies in its flexibility. It should provide the user with options of calculating emissions for actual, projected and alternate operating scenarios. These options are extremely helpful in Title V determination studies and comparisons to permit allowables where the user needs to study different aspects of the emissions scenario. Finally, the system should provide a range of output formats which allow the user to choose depending on the end use of the results: this could range from a printout of the MSDS database to a fee calculation from the actual emissions. This paper discusses all the above factors in detail with examples. Based on a study of a few available systems and feedback from their users, we believe that a flexible and efficient data management system substantially reduces the time, money and effort industry needs to spend dealing with recordkeeping and reporting.
Index Keywords: Computer software selection and evaluation; Data acquisition; Data recording; Data reduction; Database systems; Industrial emissions; User interfaces; Air emission analysis; Computerized data management system; Environmental engineering

Authors: Sharrah Lane F., Bomar Cecil R.
Title: Engine control to meet emissions requirements on natural gas fired 2-cycle engines
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Internal Combustion Engine Division (Publication) ICE
Affiliations: Advanced Control Engineering, Services, Houston, United States
Authors with affiliations: Sharrah, Lane F., Advanced Control Engineering, Services, Houston, United States; Bomar, Cecil R., Advanced Control Engineering, Services, Houston, United States
Abstract: The Natural Gas Industry has been charged with the responsibility of meeting State mandated emissions requirements based on the Clean Air Act Amendment of 1990. This has created the opportunity for many developments in methods to reduce emissions on natural gas fired 2-cycle, 4-cycle and turbine engines. Much has been learned about techniques to reduce NOx (NO and NO2), CO, THC, and VOC emissions through the use of engine hardware and automation software, some more economical than others. Original Engine Manufacturers (OEM) have learned that a linear combustion is possible through the addition of pre-combustion chambers (PCC), more efficient turbochargers, specially designed power cylinder heads as well as more efficient and more accurate ignition systems. The following addresses natural gas fired, large bore, slow speed, clean burn, 2-cycle internal combustion reciprocating engines.

Authors: Shaw E.A.G.
Title: Noise environments outdoors and the effects of community noise exposure
Affiliations: Inst. for Microstructural Sciences, National Research Council, Ottawa, Ont. K1A 0R6, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Shaw, E.A.G., Inst. for Microstructural Sciences, National Research Council, Ottawa, Ont. K1A 0R6, Canada
Abstract: Man-made noise, especially transportation noise, creates acoustical environments that are vastly different from those associated with pristine habitats. During the past 25 years, the day-night average sound level, has gained substantial acceptance as a measure of community noise exposure. During the same period, the effects of various levels of noise exposure on human activities and health have been widely studied. Data from many social surveys have been brought together and analyzed to clarify the relationship between noise exposure and the prevalence of annoyance which provides a broad indication of the impact of intrusive noise on human communities. Criteria and guidelines based on such studies are now widely used in urban planning and their effectiveness is enhanced by new standards that characterize sound propagation outdoors. Regulations that control motor vehicle noise at the source have, as yet, produced only limited benefits, while highway barriers provide some relief from excessive exposure to traffic noise. In recent years, there have been impressive reductions in the noise emissions from commercial aircraft and notable improvements in the control of airport noise. Finally, the potential effects of noise on wildlife, especially endangered species, now come under close scrutiny when noise-generating projects are planned in sensitive environments.
Index Keywords: Acoustic noise; Environmental impact; Health risks; Laws and legislation; Motor transportation; Noise pollution control; Community noise exposure; Noise environments outdoors; Noise pollution

Authors: Shearer J.C., Moore T.A.
Title: Effects of experimental coalification on texture, composition and compaction in Indonesian peat and wood
Affiliations: Research School of Earth Sciences, Victoria University of Wellington, Wellington, New Zealand; Coal Research Limited, P.O. Box 31-244, Lower Hutt, New Zealand
Authors with affiliations: Shearer, J.C., Research School of Earth Sciences, Victoria University of Wellington, Wellington, New Zealand; Moore, T.A., Coal Research Limited, P.O. Box 31-244, Lower Hutt, New Zealand
Abstract: Artificial coalification can fill a gap in our understanding of the processes of natural maturation of coal in a time frame reasonable for scientific investigation. This study focused on two main aspects of the coalification process. These aspects were, first, the effects on carbonised components in peat and, second, the amount and location of compaction during coalification. It was found that the proportion of the carbonised components increased during artificial coalification while the proportion of amorphous matrix decreased. These relative changes in proportion of constituents may be the result of the differing reactivities of these components. Compaction during artificial coalification resulted in a 72% volume loss (or a 5,7:1 compaction ratio). Most of the volume loss was from a decrease in pore space (45%) between the particles of organic material, although compression of plant parts accounts for 17% of the volume loss. The remaining 10% of the compaction was from organic mass loss, in out-gassing and fluid expulsion. Finally, although it was observed that compaction of wood was of the order of 2,5:1, it does not occur uniformly across all anatomical structures. Xylem tracheids appear to have compacted little and the majority of wood compaction appeared in the ray parenchyma. However, the compaction ratio in the rays was relatively low (1,5:1), considering that ray parenchyma should compress easily as they lack secondary cell walls and the cells thus have less inherent strength to withstand compression than xylem tracheids. However, it appears that the ray parenchyma are filled with solid organic residues at or before the time of burial, which prevents the compression of cell lumens. This suggests that the tissue would have originated from the heartwood of trees where tannins and other waste products are stored in ray parenchyma cells. Although the above observations are based on a limited sample set, the results do pose interesting subject matter for further study. In particular it is essential that different peat types be examined in order to understand the changes in proportion of organic components during coalification. It has also been demonstrated that compaction occurs mainly as a loss of pore space between organic particles; however, the degree of material loss still needs to be documented in different peats of varying decomposition states.
Author Keywords: artificial coalification; carbonised plant constituents; compaction; heartwood; Indonesian peat
Index Keywords: Amorphous materials; Compaction; Composition; Decomposition; Peat; Plants (botany); Textures; Wood; Artificial coalification; Carbonised plant constituents; Coal natural maturation; Coalification; Heartwood; Xylem tracheids; Coal; coalification; compaction; peat; wood; Indonesia

Authors: Shehata M.S.
Title: Part I. An investigation of the combustion behavior of premixing gas turbine combustor
Source title: Journal of Engineering and Applied Science
Affiliations: Benha Higher Inst of Technology, Egypt
Authors with affiliations: Shehata, M.S., Benha Higher Inst of Technology, Egypt
Abstract: An experimental study has been carried out to provide data for the design of premixing gas turbine combustor. Fuel-air mixture preparation system was designed. Mixture uniformity at combustor inlet over a wide rang of operation a modern commercial gas turbine combustor has been obtained. Special considerations are given to formation of UHC,O 2, CO, CO 2, local A/F ratio, flame temperatures, exhaust gases temperature and wall temperatures of inner and outer liners of the combustor. Primary and secondary air ratios were varied during experiments for swirl and nonswirl cases. Low emissions from premixing gas turbine combustor have been obtained. UHC and CO have been nearly disappeared from products of combustion of premixing gas turbine combustor. Total volume of premixing combustor has been decreased by 55% than a conventional diffusion combustor. Combustor wall temperatures have been kept lower than conventional diffusion combustor. Also, exhaust gases temperature was in acceptable range that makes turbine blades life long.
Index Keywords: Fuel air mixing preparation system; Premixing gas turbine combustor; Air; Combustors; Exhaust gases; Gas emissions; Gas turbines; Mixtures; Temperature; Combustion

Authors: Shen Thomas T.
Title: Pollution problems of and preventive strategies for mobile sources in developing countries
Source title: Proceedings of the Air & Waste Management Association's Annual Meeting & Exhibition
Authors with affiliations: Shen, Thomas T.
Abstract: Cars, trucks, and buses have long been mayor sources of air pollution worldwide. In response to their contribution to air quality problems, governments in developing countries have established some provisions dealing with mobile sources in their laws, regulations, and emission standards for carbon monoxide, nitrogen oxides, volatile organic compounds, and particulate, among others. Implementation of the laws, regulations, and standards depends largely upon the economic, social and cultural conditions of each of developing countries. This paper presents the preventive strategies to reduce emissions from mobile sources. Alternative sources of energy for motor vehicles and preventive technologies for eco-design vehicles and more efficient use of vehicles will be described. Discussion will include motor vehicle emission control programs and research results on alternative fuel vehicle testing in New York State.
Index Keywords: Air quality; Developing countries; Economics; Gas emissions; Ground vehicles; Laws and legislation; Standards; Synthetic fuels; Testing; Alternative fuel vehicle testing; Motor vehicle emission control program; Air pollution control

Authors: Shepard Stella, Austin Barbara, Searcy Elaine
Title: Development of a database system for monitoring and tracking transportation control measures
Source title: Proceedings of the Air & Waste Management Association's Annual Meeting & Exhibition
Authors with affiliations: Shepard, Stella; Austin, Barbara; Searcy, Elaine
Abstract: Under the Clean Air Act Amendments of 1990, severe and extreme ozone non attainment areas must adopt Transportation Control Measures (TCMs) to offset emission increases resulting from growth. TCMs must also be implemented as part of the overall strategy outlined in a State Implementation Plan (SIP) to reduce ozone precursor emissions. Many non attainment areas that are not required to implement TCMs are doing so as one element of their air quality strategies. It is challenging for localities to effectively monitor and track progress of TCM implementation and effectiveness. In many areas, such tracking requires tedious compilation of hand-written reports from numerous cities and jurisdictions within an air district. The reporting is complicated by the variation in CM program definition and implementation actions. This paper reports on a project to develop a computerized monitoring and tracking system for TCMs in Ventura, California. This database management system, the first of its kind, automates information development and reporting for TCMs.
Index Keywords: Air quality; Database systems; Gas emissions; Ozone layer; Traffic control; Transportation; Non attainment areas; State implementation plan; Transportation control measures; Air pollution control

Authors: Shimizu K.-I., Takamatsu M., Nishi K., Yoshida H., Satsuma A., Hattori T.
Title: Influence of local structure on the catalytic activity of gallium oxide for the selective reduction of NO by CH4
Affiliations: Department of Applied Chemistry, School of Engineering, Nagoya University, Chikusa-ku, Nagoya 464-01, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Shimizu, K.-I., Department of Applied Chemistry, School of Engineering, Nagoya University, Chikusa-ku, Nagoya 464-01, Japan; Takamatsu, M., Department of Applied Chemistry, School of Engineering, Nagoya University, Chikusa-ku, Nagoya 464-01, Japan; Nishi, K., Department of Applied Chemistry, School of Engineering, Nagoya University, Chikusa-ku, Nagoya 464-01, Japan; Yoshida, H., Department of Applied Chemistry, School of Engineering, Nagoya University, Chikusa-ku, Nagoya 464-01, Japan; Satsuma, A., Department of Applied Chemistry, School of Engineering, Nagoya University, Chikusa-ku, Nagoya 464-01, Japan; Hattori, T., Department of Applied Chemistry, School of Engineering, Nagoya University, Chikusa-ku, Nagoya 464-01, Japan
Abstract: NO selective reduction by CH4 over Ga2O3 catalysts is a structure-sensitive reaction depending on the local structure of Ga2O3; low-coordinate Ga ions are responsible for higher activity.

Authors: Shkolnik E., MacGregor Miller F.
Title: Differential scanning calorimetry for determining the volatility and combustibility of cement raw meal organic matter
Affiliations: Constr. Technol. Laboratories, Inc., Skokie, IL, United States
Authors with affiliations: Shkolnik, E., Constr. Technol. Laboratories, Inc., Skokie, IL, United States; MacGregor Miller, F., Constr. Technol. Laboratories, Inc., Skokie, IL, United States
Abstract: With the increasing requirements to control emissions from cement kilns, there is renewed interest in determining sources for organic materials in cement raw mixes, in the present work, the applicability of a thermoanalytical technique, differential scanning calorimetry, to determination of the presence of combustible components, their approximate abundance, and their volatility and combustibility is presented. The technique is shown to be applicable to addressing a broad scope of cement manufacturing questions concerning organic impurities. Among these questions are such issues as: • Is there a region in the limestone quarry particularly contaminated, or free of contamination? • Can we isolate and replace the raw mix component responsible for emissions? • What will be the impact of a change in the source of one or more raw materials? The DSC method is shown to be a versatile tool, effective in addressing all of these potential cement plant emission issues.
Index Keywords: Differential scanning calorimetry; Flammability; Raw materials; Volatile organic compounds; Cement raw meal organic matter; Cement manufacture

Authors: Shoaf A.R.
Title: Chemiluminescence emission during reactions between superoxide and selected aliphatic and aromatic halocarbons in aprotic media
Affiliations: Health Protection Section, Bowman Gray School of Medicine, Wake Forest University, Winston-Salem, NC 27157, United States
Authors with affiliations: Shoaf, A.R., Health Protection Section, Bowman Gray School of Medicine, Wake Forest University, Winston-Salem, NC 27157, United States
Abstract: The reactions between superoxide free radical anion (·O2-) with the halocarbons CCl4, CHCl3, BrCH2CH2Br(EDB), decachloro-biphenyl (DCBP), and 2,3,7,8-tetrachlorodibenzo-p-dioxin (TCDD) in dimethyl sulphoxide (DMSO) results in the emission of chemiluminescence (CL). The chemiluminescence reactions are characterized as having biphasic second order kinetics, CL wavelengths between 350 nm and 650 nm, and exhibiting perturbation by chemicals reactive with singlet oxygen. These data suggest that singlet oxygen species are the excited state responsible for the light emissions. Polarographic studies confirm ·O2- consumption and halide release in the reactions, while gas liquid chromatography and NBT reduction demonstrate the decomposition of the halocarbons into products. A chemiluminescent reaction mechanism is proposed involving reductive dehalogenation of the halocarbons and the generation of singlet oxygen. The significance of singlet oxygen generation is discussed with respect to a general mechanism for explaining the rapid initiation of lipid peroxidative membrane damage in halocarbon toxigenicity in animal and plant tissues. © 1996 by John Wiley & Sons, Ltd.

Authors: Shorter J.H., McManus J.B., Kolb C.E., Allwine E.J., Lamb B.K., Mosher B.W., Harriss R.C., Partchatka U., Fischer H., Harris G.W., Crutzen P.J., Karbach H.-J.
Title: Methane emission measurements in urban areas in Eastern Germany
Affiliations: Aerodyne Research, Inc., Billerica, MA, United States; Washington State University, Laboratory for Atmospheric Research, Pullman, WA, United States; Complex Systems, University of New Hampshire, Durham, NH, United States; Max-Planck Institut für Chemie, Mainz, Germany; Institut für Troposphärenforschung e.V., Leipzig, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Shorter, J.H., Aerodyne Research, Inc., Billerica, MA, United States; McManus, J.B., Aerodyne Research, Inc., Billerica, MA, United States; Kolb, C.E., Aerodyne Research, Inc., Billerica, MA, United States; Allwine, E.J., Washington State University, Laboratory for Atmospheric Research, Pullman, WA, United States; Lamb, B.K., Washington State University, Laboratory for Atmospheric Research, Pullman, WA, United States; Mosher, B.W., Complex Systems, University of New Hampshire, Durham, NH, United States; Harriss, R.C., Complex Systems, University of New Hampshire, Durham, NH, United States; Partchatka, U., Max-Planck Institut für Chemie, Mainz, Germany; Fischer, H., Max-Planck Institut für Chemie, Mainz, Germany; Harris, G.W., Max-Planck Institut für Chemie, Mainz, Germany; Crutzen, P.J., Max-Planck Institut für Chemie, Mainz, Germany; Karbach, H.-J., Institut für Troposphärenforschung e.V., Leipzig, Germany
Abstract: We have investigated methane emissions from urban sources in the former East Germany using innovative measurement techniques including a mobile real-time methane instrument and tracer release experiments. Anthropogenic and biogenic sources were studied with the emphasis on methane emissions from gas system sources, including urban distribution facilities and a production plant. Methane fluxes from pressure regulating stations ranged from 0.006 to 24. l/min. Emissions from diffuse sources in urban areas were also measured with concentration maps and whole city flux experiments. The area fluxes of the two towns studied were 0.37 and 1.9 μg/m2/s. The emissions from individual gas system stations and total town emissions of this study are comparable to results of similar sites examined in the United States.
Author Keywords: CH4 emissions; Natural gas; Tracers; Tropospheric methane
Index Keywords: methane; natural gas; air monitoring; article; Germany; urban area; anthropogenic impact; industrial emission; methane; troposphere; urban area; Germany

Authors: Sicard Matthieu, Tremblay Jean, Joubarne Luc, Hull Judith
Title: Use of economic instruments to reduce NOx emissions from mobile sources in Quebec
Source title: Proceedings of the Air & Waste Management Association's Annual Meeting & Exhibition
Authors with affiliations: Sicard, Matthieu; Tremblay, Jean; Joubarne, Luc; Hull, Judith
Abstract: In 1990 the Canadian Council of Ministers of the Environment (CCME) adopted a Management Plan to reduce NOx and VOC emissions in order to meet the 82 ppb Canadian objective for tropospheric ozone. It is within the Windsor-Quebec City Corridor (WQC) that are recorded the highest frequency and the longest duration of ozone episodes. In the Province of Quebec, 80% of NOx and close to 40% of VOCs emissions can be traced back to mobile sources. Therefore, any credible control strategies would have to involve all on road vehicles. An in-depth evaluation of three economic instruments for control of mobile NOx sources in the Quebec portion of the WQC was conducted by Cogesult Inc. and Environment Canada. These were: an emissions-based vehicle registration charge, an emissions-based vehicle tax and a vehicle scrappage programme. This paper provides an overview of the evaluation of these instruments which involved: a complete description of the programme design (including monitoring, enforcement, implementation and operating costs, administrative and jurisdictional issues), a socio-economic impact assessment (costs and benefits to industry, consumers and governments and indirect impacts such as inflation, employment and competitiveness), a comparative assessment (comparing the advantages and disadvantages of the selected instruments with those of other management activities involving both mobile and stationary sources), and a conclusion on the pertinence of using these instruments with the consideration of other applicable economic instruments.
Index Keywords: Economic and social effects; Industrial economics; Industrial emissions; Nitrogen oxides; Taxation; Economic instruments; Vehicle registration charge; Vehicle tax; Air pollution control

Authors: Siegler Mark S.
Title: State/federal partnership for compliance training
Source title: Proceedings of the Air & Waste Management Association's Annual Meeting & Exhibition
Authors with affiliations: Siegler, Mark S.
Abstract: The California Air Resources Board (CARB) has had an established uniform air pollution control program since 1986, which trained federal, state, and local air pollution staff statewide. The U.S. EPA established requirements for federal inspector training and voluntary guidelines for state inspectors in 1988. U.S. EPA recognized the CARB program as a model state training program and wanted other states to have the opportunity to participate and benefit. Thus, after a number of years of smaller cooperative projects, in 1993, a multi-year innovative state/federal partnership for compliance training between the U.S. EPA Stationary Source Compliance Division (now called the Air Enforcement Division) and state and local agencies was established. This partnership was to demonstrate and deliver onsite CARB 100 Series basic compliance inspector training and to demonstrate, develop, and deliver CARB 200 Series specific source category training. The program has been highly successful over the past three years and is currently in its fourth year of operation. This paper discusses this effective partnership; describes how the training program was established, identifies the curriculum, provides details on current activities, highlight the benefits, and discusses plans for the future.
Index Keywords: Environmental protection; Laws and legislation; Personnel training; Societies and institutions; Standards; Compliance training; State federal partnership; Air pollution control

Authors: Siemers W.T., Tisdale M.G., Hallenbeck L.D., Howard J.J., Prezbindowski D.R.
Title: Depositional facies and diagenetic history: Keys to reservoir porosity, quality and performance, east vacuum grayburg- san andres unit, lea county, New Mexico
Source title: Society of Petroleum Engineers - Permian Basin Oil and Gas Recovery Conference, OGR 1996
Affiliations: Phillips Petroleum Company, United States; International Petrology Research Inc., United States
Authors with affiliations: Siemers, W.T., Phillips Petroleum Company, United States; Tisdale, M.G., Phillips Petroleum Company, United States; Hallenbeck, L.D., Phillips Petroleum Company, United States; Howard, J.J., Phillips Petroleum Company, United States; Prezbindowski, D.R., International Petrology Research Inc., United States
Abstract: The East Vacuum Grayburg-San Andres Unit (EVGSAU) is located in the Permian Basin, Lea County, New Mexico. The EVGSAU was unitized in 1978 and has been under waterflood operations since 1979. CO2/water injection (WAG injection) commenced in 1986. An interdisciplinary reservoir study was initiated in 1994 to integrate the unit's geological character and reservoir performance in order to optimize the CO2/waterflood. This paper examines the sedimentologic and stratigraphic framework, lithologic character, pore system, quality and continuity, and architecture and internal geometry of the reservoir and their application to safeguarding prime CO2 flood performance within the reservoir. The Permian-aged San Andres Formation is composed of two major, eustatically controlled, upward-shallowing carbonate ramp sequences that contain multiple, anhydritic, dolomitized successions in which subtidal grain-rich lithofacies grade upward into peritidal, mud-rich carbonates and siliciclastics. A siliciclastic, lowstand tidal flat unit, the Lovington sand, caps the lower sequence and separates the formation into the Lower and Upper San Andres. Grainstones and packstones deposited as high- energy shoals and bars are the primary reservoir lithologies. Diagenetic processes critical to the development of good reservoir porosity and quality are; (1) early dolomitization of the carbonate section, (2) intense dissolution and alteration of anhydrite to gypsum, and (3) dissolution of dolomite. Four correlatable subtidal grain-rich intervals constitute the chief flow units and the only continuous waterfloodable intervals across the field. Relationships between the distribution of the subtidal grain-rich lithofacies, porosity content, anhydrite and gypsum abundances, and structural position exhibit considerable potential for mapping reservoir flow units and for defining reservoir quality within flow units. This geological model provided the architectural basis for the reservoir simulation pattern model used to evaluate reservoir performance and to modify EVGSAU operating plans to ensure optimum flooding. The geological model helped determine; 1) Upper San Andres vs. Lower San Andres performance, 2) infill spacing within the Upper and Lower San Andres, 3) the potential for horizontal injection in the Upper and Lower San Andres, and 4) repressurization volumes required for the Upper San Andres. © 1996, Society of Petroleum Engineers, Inc.
Index Keywords: Carbon dioxide; Deposition; Dissolution; Floods; Geologic models; Gypsum; Plastic flow; Porosity; Reservoirs (water); Stratigraphy; Diagenetic process; Geological character; Geological modeling; Reservoir performance; Reservoir porosity; Reservoir quality; Reservoir simulation; Stratigraphic framework; Petroleum reservoir evaluation

Authors: Sierhuis W.M., De Vries C., Born J.G.P.
Title: pcdd/f emissions related to the operating conditions of the flue gas cleaning system of MWI-Amsterdam
Affiliations: City Refuse Disposal Dept., Amsterdam, Netherlands; Waste Processing Association, Utrecht, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Sierhuis, W.M., City Refuse Disposal Dept., Amsterdam, Netherlands; De Vries, C., City Refuse Disposal Dept., Amsterdam, Netherlands; Born, J.G.P., Waste Processing Association, Utrecht, Netherlands
Abstract: This paper presents the results of three optimization programmes with the object of reducing dioxin/furan emissions from Amsterdam Municipal Refuse Incineration Plant. Special importance is attached to the minimization of the de-novo synthesis in the first electrostatic precipitator (fly ash extraction). Similarly, the possibilities for improving the absorption of dioxin/furan in spray absorbers are considered. In conclusion, the paper reports on the effect of adding activated carbon to the second wet cleaning system.

Authors: Simmers T.A., Van Den Bosch J., Vasmel W.L.E.
Title: Tropical pyomyositis in a temperature climate: A case report
Affiliations: St. Lucas Hospital, PO Box 9243, 1006 AE Amsterdam, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Simmers, T.A., St. Lucas Hospital, PO Box 9243, 1006 AE Amsterdam, Netherlands; Van Den Bosch, J., St. Lucas Hospital, PO Box 9243, 1006 AE Amsterdam, Netherlands; Vasmel, W.L.E., St. Lucas Hospital, PO Box 9243, 1006 AE Amsterdam, Netherlands
Abstract: Pyomyositis is an abscess-forming infection of large skeletal muscles, usually with Staphylococcus aureus. Although it is common in the tropics and relatively rare in temperate climates, imported cases due to growing global mobility may be expected to increase its incidence outside tropical regions. Early diagnosis and correct management are imperative in this a potentially fatal disorder, and require a high degree of clinical suspicion. A case report is presented demonstrating typical aspects of diagnosis and treatment.
Author Keywords: Pyomyositis; Staphylococcus aureus

Authors: Simmons J.A., Fernandez I.J., Briggs R.D., Delaney M.T.
Title: Forest floor carbon pools and fluxes along a regional climate gradient in Maine, USA
Affiliations: Dept. of Appl. Ecol./Environ. Sci., 5722 Deering Hall, University of Maine, Orono, ME 04469-5722, United States; Cooperative Forestry Research Unit, Nutting Hall, University of Maine, Orono, ME 04469, United States; Coillte Teoranta, Irish Forestry Board, Bray, Ireland; Biology Department, West Virginia Wesleyan College, Buckhannon, WV 26201, United States
Authors with affiliations: Simmons, J.A., Dept. of Appl. Ecol./Environ. Sci., 5722 Deering Hall, University of Maine, Orono, ME 04469-5722, United States, Biology Department, West Virginia Wesleyan College, Buckhannon, WV 26201, United States; Fernandez, I.J., Dept. of Appl. Ecol./Environ. Sci., 5722 Deering Hall, University of Maine, Orono, ME 04469-5722, United States; Briggs, R.D., Cooperative Forestry Research Unit, Nutting Hall, University of Maine, Orono, ME 04469, United States; Delaney, M.T., Coillte Teoranta, Irish Forestry Board, Bray, Ireland
Abstract: Global carbon (C) reserves in soil are large compared with atmospheric stocks (in the form of CO2 and methane), so small changes in soil C storage will have a significant effect on atmospheric CO2 concentrations. In order to better understand the consequences of global climate change, it is essential that we define how soil C storage is influenced by changes in temperature and moisture that are expected as a result of global climate change. Forest floor carbon pools and fluxes were evaluated at 16 northern hardwood sites located within four distinct climate regions (Northern, Central, Southern and Coastal) in Maine. Mean annual air temperature at the sites ranged from 2.0°C in the Northern region to 6.2°C in the Coastal region and average annual precipitation ranged from 90 cm in the Northern region to 140 cm in the Coastal region. Leaf litter mass and leaf litter C flux were not correlated with temperature indices and did not vary among regions. However, they were positively correlated with annual precipitation, suggesting that litter production was controlled, in part at least, by precipitation but not by temperature. Northern sites stored more C in the forest floor than Coastal sites, and they experienced slower decomposition rates. Because soil and vegetation characteristics of these sites were similar, we attribute these trends to differences in climate. Indeed, C turnover time was correlated with latitude and temperature indices. Slower decomposition in the Northern region was attributed to a combination of lower specific activity at temperatures below 13°C, cooler average temperatures and a shorter frost-free season. Soil respiration at each site was positively correlated with temperature and the slope of the relationship increased with latitude, indicating that the ability of the soil biota to respire C varied with climate. A predictive equation is presented that accounts for the change in slope with latitude. Because C loss through soil respiration was more sensitive to temperature than C inputs from litter, any regional warming in the next century may lead to a decrease in forest floor carbon storage. However, if precipitation increases with temperature, then litter C flux may increase and offset the increase in soil respiration.
Author Keywords: Decomposition; Litter; Moisture; Soil respiration; Temperature
Index Keywords: cellular organisms; cellular organisms; carbon flux; carbon pool; climatic change; decomposition; forest; soil respiration; temperature; USA, Maine

Authors: Simmons Jr. J.L., Backus M.M.
Title: Waveform-based AVO inversion and AVO prediction-error
Affiliations: Department of Geological Sciences, University of Texas at Austin; Bureau of Economic Geology, University Station, Box X, Austin, TX 78713-7908, United States; Department of Geological Sciences, University of Texas at Austin, P.O. Box 7909, Austin, TX 78713-7909, United States
Authors with affiliations: Simmons Jr., J.L., Department of Geological Sciences, University of Texas at Austin, Bureau of Economic Geology, University Station, Box X, Austin, TX 78713-7908, United States; Backus, M.M., Department of Geological Sciences, University of Texas at Austin, P.O. Box 7909, Austin, TX 78713-7909, United States
Abstract: A practical approach to linear prestack seismic inversion in the context of a locally 1-D earth is employed to use amplitude variation with offset (AVO) information for the direct detection in hydrocarbons. The inversion is based on the three-term linearized approximation to the Zoeppritz equations. The normal-incidence compressional-wave reflection coefficient Ro models the background reflectivity in the absence of hydrocarbons and incorporates the mudrock curve and Gardner's equation. Prediction-error parameters, ΔRsh and ΔRρ, represent perturbations in the normal-incidence shear-wave reflection coefficient and the density contribution to the normal incidence reflectivity, respectively, from that predicted by the mudrock curve and Gardner's equation. This prediction-error approach can detect hydrocarbons in the absence of an overall increase in AVO, and in the absence of bright spots, as expected in theory. Linear inversion is applied to a portion of a young, Tertiary, shallow-marine data set that contains known hydrocarbon accumulations. Prestack data are in the form of angle stack, or constant offset-to-depth ratio, gathers. Prestack synthetic seismograms are obtained by primaries-only ray tracing using the linearized approximation to the Zoeppritz equations to model the reflection amplitudes. Where the a priori assumptions hold, the data are reproduced with a single parameter Ro. Hydrocarbons are detected as low impedance relative to the surrounding shales and the downdip brine-filled reservoir on Ro, also as positive perturbations (opposite polarity relative to Ro) on Δsh and ΔRρ. The maximum perturbation in ΔRsh, from the normal-incidence shearwave reflection coefficient predicted by the a priori assumptions is 0.08. Hydrocarbon detection is achieved, although the overall seismic response of a gas-filled thin layer shows a decrease in amplitude with offset (angle). The angle-stack data (70 prestack ensembles, 0.504-1.936 s time range) are reproduced with a data residual that is 7 dB down. Reflectivity-based prestack seismograms properly model a gas/water contact as a strong increase in AVO and a gas-filled thin layer as a decrease in AVO.
Index Keywords: Acoustic wave reflection; Approximation theory; Differential equations; Hydrocarbons; Mathematical models; Perturbation techniques; Petroleum prospecting; Petroleum reservoirs; Seismic waves; Seismographs; Statistical methods; Amplitude variation with offset (AVO); Compressional waves; Gardner's equation; Hydrocarbon detection; Linear prestack seismic inversion; Mudrock curve; Prediction error parameters; Reflection coefficient; Zoeppritz equation; Seismic prospecting; AVO; hydrocarbon; inversion; mudstone; seismic reflection

Authors: Simmons P.R., Cavanaugh S.
Title: Relationships among childhood parental care, professional school climate, and nursing student caring ability
Affiliations: Pennsylvania State University, Hershey, PA, United States; Emig Research Center, York Hospital, York, PA, United States; Pennsylvania State University, 20 Briarcrest Sq., Hershey, PA 17033, United States
Authors with affiliations: Simmons, P.R., Pennsylvania State University, Hershey, PA, United States, Pennsylvania State University, 20 Briarcrest Sq., Hershey, PA 17033, United States; Cavanaugh, S., Emig Research Center, York Hospital, York, PA, United States
Abstract: A mailed random-sample survey of 350 senior baccalaureate nursing students explored relationships among early maternal and paternal care, the caring climate of nursing schools, and caring ability. Caring ability was quantified with the Caring Ability Inventory. Maternal and paternal care were measured with the Parental Bonding Instrument. School climate was measured on the Charles F. Kettering School Climate Inventory. There is no linear correlation between level of maternal or paternal care and subsequent caring ability (r= -.01 and 0.01, respectively). However, a curvilinear relationship exists: Those with higher caring are respondents who scored both at the highest and the lowest levels of maternal care. Moreover, levels of caring within nursing schools appear to moderate caring ability developed at home. A caring school climate is the strongest predictor of caring ability (r = 0.16, P < .01). Thus, it is of concern to note that only 52 per cent of the respondents rated their schools high in caring. Caring is a valued attribute in professional nursing. If this quality is to flourish, it must be cultivated within the climate of nursing schools that exert a major professional socializing influence on future nurses. Copyright © 1996 by W.B. Saunders Company.
Author Keywords: Caring; Caring ability; Maternal care; School climate

Authors: Simondi-Teisseire B., Viana B., Vivien D., Lejus A.M.
Title: Optical investigation of Er:Ca2Al2SiO7 and Yb:Ca2Al2SiO7 for laser applications in the near infrared
Affiliations: Lab. de Chim. Appl., l'Etat Solide, URA 1466 du CNRS, ENSCP, 11 Rue P. and M. Curie, F-76321 Paris Cédex 05, France
Authors with affiliations: Simondi-Teisseire, B., Lab. de Chim. Appl., l'Etat Solide, URA 1466 du CNRS, ENSCP, 11 Rue P. and M. Curie, F-76321 Paris Cédex 05, France; Viana, B., Lab. de Chim. Appl., l'Etat Solide, URA 1466 du CNRS, ENSCP, 11 Rue P. and M. Curie, F-76321 Paris Cédex 05, France; Vivien, D., Lab. de Chim. Appl., l'Etat Solide, URA 1466 du CNRS, ENSCP, 11 Rue P. and M. Curie, F-76321 Paris Cédex 05, France; Lejus, A.M., Lab. de Chim. Appl., l'Etat Solide, URA 1466 du CNRS, ENSCP, 11 Rue P. and M. Curie, F-76321 Paris Cédex 05, France
Abstract: Single crystals of the aluminosilicate Ca2Al2SiO7 (CAS) activated with Er3+ or Yb3+ were grown by the floating zone method for several dopant contents. The crystals of good optical quality, were investigated using optical spectroscopy with the aim to assess their potential interest as laser materials in the 1.5 μAm (Er: CAS) and 1 μm (Yb:CAS) range, respectively. In both cases, absorption, siimulated emission, and gain cross sections were determined. Radiative and experimental lifetimes were also calculated. In the two compounds, as the two levels involved in the transitions are the ground and first excited states, radiation trapping and energy migration occur. For Er:CAS, emission around 1.55 μm (in the middle of the eye-safe range) may be obtained for a reasonable value of the population inversion ratio β(β = 0.4). The Judd-Ofelt parameters are significantly higher than those of Er:YAG and the nonradiative relaxation of the excited states located above 4I13/2 is fast (phonon energy cut-off around 1020cm-1) ensuring efficient population of the 4I13/2 emitting level. For Yb:CAS, the absorption and emission cross sections are higher than for Er:CAS. Positive gain cross section is possible for very low β values, for instance β= 0.04 at 1045 nm. Taking into account the pump saturation intensity and the β value, it appears that this compound should be one of the best ytterbium activated laser crystal (if one excepts the apatite-type hosts).
Index Keywords: Aluminum compounds; Crystal growth; Crystal impurities; Silicates; Single crystals; Solid state lasers; Aluminosilicates; Laser materials; Optical materials

Authors: Simpson R.G.
Title: Relationships between self-help health organizations and professional health care providers
Source title: Health and Social Care in the Community
Affiliations: Department of Social Services, Loughborough University, United Kingdom; Direct. of Psychiat. for the Elderly, Towers Hospital, Gipsy Lane, Leicester, LE5OTD, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Simpson, R.G., Department of Social Services, Loughborough University, United Kingdom, Direct. of Psychiat. for the Elderly, Towers Hospital, Gipsy Lane, Leicester, LE5OTD, United Kingdom
Abstract: This paper discusses areas of conflict in the relationships between professional and lay knowledge and values, in the context of disease-specific self-help groups. In the current climate of Government emphasis on consumer satisfaction, and local voice initiatives, collaboration amongst professionals, clients and consumers has become of increased importance. Agreement and harmony between professional and lay care-givers is essential to the development of improved and extended health care provision. Findings from a study of patients who have undergone open heart surgery, and their families, are used to identifiy areas of conflicts generally, between professional and lay discourses, and illustrates these problem areas by examples found in the individual self-help group study. If the highest possible quality of health care is to be achieved, both professional and lay discourses should be of value, and both contribute to patients' well-being and recovery. Professional courses should include information and training on consumer issues, and mutual support principles. © 1996 Blackwell Science Ltd.
Author Keywords: Cardiac surgery; Conflict; Health professionals; Self-help

Authors: Sims H.
Title: The unsheltering sky: China, India, and the montreal protocol
Authors with affiliations: Sims, H.
Abstract: The cooperation of China and India in replacing chemicals that damage the stratospheric ozone layer is critical to the success of the world's first environmental agreement, the Montreal Protocol. China's leaders accepted the agreement more readily than did their Indian counterparts. These divergent responses are attributed to the nature of the policy issue in question, the impact of regime type upon state leaders environmental policies, and dissimilar linkages between international and domestic actors and forces.
Index Keywords: climate policy; developing country; environmental management; environmental policy; international agreement; international environmental policy; Montreal Protocol; ozone depletion; China; India

Abstract: A series of iron-lithium mixed molybdates of the general formula LixFe1-xMoO4 (x = 0.45-0.55) was synthesized and characterized by XRD and Mössbauer spectroscopy. The modification of this system by a Li to Fe ratio variation at constant (Li + Fe) content gives an opportunity to study structure-activity relations in catalytic methane oxidation to formaldehyde. Other products registered by means of gas chromatography are ethane and carbon oxides. Reduction and oxidation of the samples was also studied. The influence of stoichiometry of the mixed molybdates on their structure, ion state in the lattice and consequently on their catalytic performance was evaluated.
Author Keywords: Iron-lithium mixed molybdate catalyst; Methane oxidation; Mössbauer spectroscopy

Authors: Sirisriro R., Podoloff D.A., Patt Y.Z., Curley S.A., Kasi L.P., Bhadkamkar V.A., Kim E.E., Murray J.L., Haynie T.P., Smith R.
Title: 99tcm-immu4 imaging in recurrent colorectal cancer efficacyand impact on surgical management
Affiliations: Department of Nuclear Medicine, Division of Diagnostic Imaging, University of Texas M.D. Anderson Cancer Center, 1515 Holcombe Boulevard, Houston, TX, United States; Department of Nuclear Medicine, Division of Imaging, University of Texas M.D. Anderson Cancer Center, 1515 Holcombe Boulevard, Houston, TX, United States; Department of Medical Oncology, Division of Medicine, University of Texas M.D. Anderson Cancer Center, 1515 Holcombe Boulevard, Houston, TX, United States; Department of General Surgery, Division of Surgery, University of Texas M.D. Anderson Cancer Center, 1515 Holcombe Boulevard, Houston, TX, United States; Department of Immunology and Biological Therapy, Division of Medicine, University of Texas M.D. Anderson Cancer Center, 1515 Holcombe Boulevard, Houston, TX, United States

Abstract: The aims of this study were to evaluate the efficacy of scintigraphy with the 99Tcm-labelled anti-carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) monoclonal antibody Fab' fragment (IMMU4) in the diagnosis of recurrent colorectal carcinoma and to investigate its usefulness in the intraoperative surgical management of patients undergoing re-operation because of a rising serum CEA. We evaluated 24 patients prospectively who had rising serum CEA 6–19 months after initial surgery for colorectal carcinoma. Ten patients had lesions confirmed by computed tomography, ultrasound, magnetic resonance imaging, endoscopic examination or barium enema. Fourteen patients had negative findings on one or more of the above studies, but were suspected of having occult disease from their rising serum CEA. All patients were scheduled for surgery for restaging during a 'second look' procedure. Planar and single photon emission tomography (SPET) imaging was performed in all patients. All scintigraphic findings were correlated with surgical and histopathological results. The overall sensitivity, specificity and accuracy were 81,90 and 86% respectively when analysed by lesion, and 95, 60 and 88% respectively when analysed by patient. Ten of 14 (71%) patients with occult disease were correctly diagnosed as having recurrent disease. The SPET images were shown to have superior detectability (80%) compared with the planar images (35%). The surgeon judged the study to have had a neutral impact in 75% of the patients, but to have been helpful in 25%. We conclude that this antibody is potentially useful in detecting recurrent colorectal carcinoma in patients with rising serum CEA, especially when conventional imaging is negative or equivocal. It can also be helpful in altering planned surgery. © 1996 Lippincott-Raven Publishers.

Authors: Siskind D.E., Russell III J.M.
Title: Coupling between middle and upper atmospheric NO: Constraints from HALOE observations

Hulburt Ctr. for Space Res., Naval Research Laboratory, Code 7641, Washington, DC 20375, United States; Russell III, J.M., Atmospheric Sciences Division, NASA Langley Research Center, Atmospheric Sciences Division, NASA Langley Research Center, Hampton, VA 23681, United States
Abstract: Observations of NO, NO2, and CH4 from the HALOE instrument on the UARS satellite are used to investigate the transport of thermospheric NO into the middle atmosphere. By comparing the variation of NO and NO2 with simultaneous measurements of a long lived stratospheric tracer like CH4, regions of enhanced odd nitrogen can be quantified. Our results indicate substantial enhancement of NO in the high latitude winter mesosphere extending from thermospheric altitudes down to about 55-60 km. We also see evidence of substantial equatorward mixing of mesospheric NO. Occasional enhancements of NOx are seen extending down into the upper stratosphere in winter; however, they do not appear to persist. Observations by HALOE at latitudes up to 75-80 degrees in early spring show no evidence for enhanced NOx. This suggests that the effect of thermospheric NO on high latitude upper stratospheric O3 may be less than previously thought.
Index Keywords: halogen occultation experiment; meridional transport; nitrogen; nitrogen layer; ozone depletion; stratospheric tracer gas; thermospheric nitrogen oxide; UARS; Earth sciences; Geophysics; High Latitudes; Middle atmosphere; Odd nitrogen; Simultaneous measurement; Stratospheric tracers; Nitrogen oxides

Authors: Sistla G., Zhou N., Hao W., Ku J.-Y., Rao S.T., Bornstein R., Freedman F., Thunis P.
Title: Effects of uncertainties in meteorological inputs on urban airshed model predictions and ozone control strategies
Affiliations: Division of Air Resources, New York Stt. Dept. Environ. C., Albany, NY 12233, United States; Department of Meteorology, San Jose State University, San Jose, CA 95192, United States; Environmental Institute, Europ. Comm. Jt. Research Institute, 21020 Ispra, Italy

Environ. C., Albany, NY 12233, United States; Rao, S.T., Division of Air Resources, New York Stt. Dept. Environ. C., Albany, NY 12233, United States; Bornstein, R., Department of Meteorology, San Jose State University, San Jose, CA 95192, United States; Freedman, F., Department of Meteorology, San Jose State University, San Jose, CA 95192, United States; Thunis, P., Environmental Institute, Europ. Comm. Jt. Research Institute, 21020 Ispra, Italy
Abstract: Although well-recognized within the photochemical modeling community, the effect of uncertainties in meteorological input on the urban airshed model (UAM) output has not been systematically evaluated. In this study, the UAM has been applied to investigate the sensitivity of ozone predictions to the choices in wind fields and mixing height profiles for the data-sparse New York metropolitan area. A set of three wind fields, in combination with spatially varying and spatially invariant mixing heights, is investigated for the July 1988 ozone episode. In general, model-predicted ozone levels were higher under the spatially varying mixing height (SVM) option than under the spatially invariant mixing height (SIM) option. SVM-based UAM simulations provided better agreement between the predicted and measured ozone concentrations than SIM-based UAM simulations. However, from the regulatory standpoint, predicted ozone concentrations based on either of these mixing height options are within the range considered as acceptable. UAM simulations with emission reductions of 75% NO(x) and 25% VOCs (NO(x)-focused) reveal that the improvement in peak ozone levels under the SIM option is larger than that under the SVM option, whereas the emission reduction scenario of 25% NO(x) and 75% VOCs (VOC-focused) yields greater improvement in peak ozone under the SVM option than with the SIM option. Given the strong influence of mixing heights and wind fields on UAM model predictions in data-sparse areas, it is imperative that uncertainties in development of ozone abatement plans be quantified.
Author Keywords: Meteorological inputs; Ozone control; UAM
